title: Set up a new project
text:
Create a new project in Nvivo
Open NVivo and click the â€˜New Projectâ€™ tile on the welcome page.
If you already have a project open in NVivo, go to â€˜Fileâ€™ on the ribbon and select â€˜Newâ€™. **Insert screenshot of opening a new project


Project setup
Add a project title.
The file name will be automatically generated, but you may want to adjust where this is being saved to.
You can enter a description of the project at this stage as well. While not required, itâ€™s good practice to include something here.
Next, choose your preferred save and recovery settings.
NB: the default settings are to have autosave disabled with save prompts every 15 minutes, which is quite useful. If you turn on autosave, undo functions are disabled.
**Insert screenshot


Optional tour

You will be prompted to take a quick tour of Nvivo, which will outline:
+ Importing data + Cases + Notes + Queries + Visualizations + Centralizing workflow
Skip for now â€“ but may be worth coming back to in the future.

title: Organising codes
text:
Connections between codes
After a few rounds of open coding, and some reflection as you along, some hierarchical structures might emerge.






ğŸ¤” Critical Considerations



Look at your open codes and ask yourself:

Are there any common themes that might make a good â€˜parent codeâ€™?
Do any codes refer to a theme or idea that may be experienced in a number of different ways (different sources, targets, circumstances, etc.)?
Are there any common categories that would be useful to think with across many codes and examples?
Do some of your codes exist within a common theme that could become a parent code?
Does it make sense to nest down, or create a new top code?




NVivo jargon: top level codes are called â€˜parent codesâ€™; sub-codes are called â€˜child codesâ€™.



Hierachical tree coding

As weâ€™ve already shown you, you can create a new parent code and drag in existing codes as sub-codes
You can also create new â€˜child nodesâ€™ i.e.Â subcodes of existing codes.
You can collapse codes by right clicking->copy- Merge into selected code




Recommendations

For beginners, and at the very start of coding, 2 levels are probably enough
More than 3-4 levels becomes unwieldy

title: Resources
text:
Recommended Reading

Qualitative Analysis Software
The best texts on using software for qualitative analysis:

Jackson, Kristi, and Pat Bazeley. (2019) Qualitative Data Analysis with NVivo. 3rd ed.Â Thousand Oaks, CA: SAGE Publications Ltd.

PDF for Chapter 1 - â€˜Where to begin?â€™
Click by click instructions accompanying the book.

Bazeley, Pat. (2017) â€˜Using Qualitative Data Analysis Software (QDAS) to Assist Data Analysesâ€™. Pp. 1â€“18 in Handbook of Research Methods in Health Social Sciences, edited by P. Liamputtong. Singapore: Springer.

Open access copy.




Qualitative Analysis - how to resources
Also useful as a basis for understanding qualitative analysis, coding, and writing up more generally:

Bazeley, Pat. 2020. Qualitative Data Analysis: Practical Strategies. 2nd ed.Â London: SAGE Pubications.

Hard-copies available in most university libraries.

SaldaÃ±a, Johnny. (2013) The Coding Manual for Qualitative Researchers. 2nd ed.Â London: Sage Publications Ltd.

An Introduction to Codes and Coding PDF of Chapter 1.




Examples of applied use of NVivo

Byrne, David. (2022) â€˜A Worked Example of Braun and Clarkeâ€™s Approach to Reflexive Thematic Analysisâ€™. Quality & Quantity 56(3):1391â€“1412. doi: 10.1007/s11135-021-01182-y.
Hutchison, Andrew John, Lynne Halley Johnston, and Jeff David Breckon. (2010) â€˜Using QSRâ€NVivo to Facilitate the Development of a Grounded Theory Project: An Account of a Worked Exampleâ€™. International Journal of Social Research Methodology 13(4):283â€“302. doi: 10.1080/13645570902996301.



Other qualitative analysis software
Nvivo is the market leader but some other popular ones are listed below:
Subscription/licenced software:

title: Adding metadata
text:
Right now, when we look at our cases, they donâ€™t have attributes or metadata:

Now we will create â€˜case classificationsâ€™, bringing in the metadata related to each file or individual.
This could be any number of things, for example socio-demographics like age or gender, or that personâ€™s response to a survey.

Metadata file
In the project files you downloaded, in the folder â€˜research toolsâ€™, open and check the excel sheet entitled â€˜metadataâ€™:

This file contains information on our participants from the 2016 interviews. We are trying to match this with our existing case classification of â€˜Peopleâ€™, so we need to make sure itâ€™s formatted the same way to enable it to match.
So check that:

The first column - â€˜Peopleâ€™- indicate the cases. Check this is typed the same way in your Nvivo project setup.
The names in this first column should match the formatting of the cases and the interview file names in Nvivo - and this is case sensitive (i.e.Â if itâ€™s vince it must also be â€˜vinceâ€™ and not â€˜Vinceâ€™)




Import classification sheet


From the Import ribbon tab, select â€˜classificationsâ€™ and then â€˜Import classification sheetsâ€™.



Select the â€˜metadata.xlsâ€™ file from the â€˜Research toolsâ€™ folder.
Click Open to select file.
Then click Next on the import Wizard:



Set classification type as â€˜case classificationâ€™.

You can select or deselect if you want to create new attributes, update existing classifications, or replace existing attribute values.

Click Next.


N.B. to set up â€˜file classificationsâ€™, follow the same process but select â€˜file classificationsâ€™ here (might include similar demographic info as well as things like location of interview, who interviewer was, time, date, etc.)


Choose to represent files â€˜as hierarchical namesâ€™; click next.




Select how you want blank attributes, dates, time and numbers to be represented.


Click finish.


Now, check that case info has been imported to existing â€˜Peopleâ€™ classification. You can see that the first row of the excel sheet linked with the cases that already existed, and now you have columns indicating exactly the columns that were in the spreadsheet.



Manually add new cases

Click on the â€˜casesâ€™ on left hand menu, then right click on the open space in the â€˜List Viewâ€™ under your cases and select â€˜New Caseâ€™, or use shortcut or Ctrl+Shift+N.




Input any name / description for the case under â€˜Generalâ€™





Select relevant attributes under â€˜Attribute valuesâ€™
Select case classification as â€˜Peopleâ€™
You can assign values from the drop down box for each attribute

Select OK.


You can see a new case for â€˜rogerâ€™ has been set up; it doesnâ€™t have any files or attributes attached yet.



Create new attributes for an existing case
You might want to create a new attribute i.e.Â a new column in the metadata for some feature which varies between your cases.
We are going to create a new attribute â€˜2015 pre-electionâ€™ that indicates whether they also took part in the 2016 pre-election focus group.


Click on Case Classifications-> People
In the home ribbon, go to Case classification -> new attribute





In the â€˜Generalâ€™ tab, enter the name (â€˜2015 pre-electionâ€™) and a description, then move to the â€˜Valuesâ€™ tab.





Another way to do this is, within a case, scroll to the bottom of the list of attributes and click new attribute (step 1 below)
Then follow the same steps as above





Click the values tab to assign possible options for the attribute
We are going to make this yes/ no, so click â€˜Addâ€™ -> enter â€˜Yesâ€™, â€˜Addâ€™ -> enter â€˜noâ€™
Select â€˜OKâ€™ /done:



N.B. default is set to â€˜unassignedâ€™ â€“ you can change this depending on your preference
Now this column will appear as the last column in your case classifications sheet, but it is empty with no values (i.e.Â â€˜unassignedâ€™)


You can set values for this new attribute by clicking on the drop-down arrow.





Summarise metadata in charts
Now that you have some basic information attached to the transcripts, you can summarize this in a basic way using Nvivoâ€™s chart function. This depends very much on how the metadata in the classification sheet are formatted, but so long as this is consistent, it can be very useful for getting a quick glance at your sample composition.
For example, here we want to understand voting patterns within the sample.


In the top ribbon, go to the â€˜Exploreâ€™ tab, and choose â€˜chartâ€™





On the chart wizard, choose â€˜casesâ€™, then â€˜nextâ€™.





At the next stage, choose â€˜cases by attribute value for an attributeâ€™ - this will chart the values of one attribute/variable. You have the choice to chart two attributes at the same time, this will create a 3 way bar chart. But letâ€™s just do one at a time for this example.





At the next stage, select the attribute you want to chart by clicking â€˜selectâ€™
Then expand the list of attributes by clicking the plus symbol next to â€˜Peopleâ€™
Choose â€˜2016 voteâ€™, and click OK.





Finally, you get the choice of how the values of the attribute are displayed on the x-axis. We leave it as the default, but you can choose alphabetical etc. Click finish.




Now you will see a simple bar chart displayed. You can edit the title, labels etc and much more in the top ribbon. You can also export or print chart (1).
You can just see a numerical summary (rather than the bar chart) by clicking â€˜summaryâ€™ on the far right of the screen (2)
Note there is 1 case for whom this attribute is blank or â€˜unassignedâ€™- this is roger, the case we just created. (3)
There are many more complex charts you can create once you have more complex and appropriately formatted data; you can also make charts based on codes you have created.

title: Building Themes
text:
Framework Matrices

Creating a Framework Matrix

Notes > Framework Matrices


Right-click in white space.
Select â€˜New Framework Matrixâ€¦â€™



Provide it with a suitable name.



Select the Rows tab.
Use the left-hand â€˜Selectâ€™ button to open a dialogue and select the Participant case folder.
Use the right-hand â€˜Selectâ€™ button to open a dialogue and select 1-4 attributes from the People classification that will be used to sort how the rows for participant cases will be ordered.
(Optional) if you pick more than one attribute, you can use the up/down arrows on the right, in blue, to change their order.



Select the Colums tab.
Use the â€˜Selectâ€™ button to pick codes to use as columns, in this case select the â€˜Auto-Code (Sections)â€™ folder.
(Optional) use the arrows on the right to change the order of the codes.

Hit â€˜OKâ€™ and after a few seconds the Framework Matrix will have been created and will automatically open.


Viewing a Framework Matrix
When viewing a framework matrix, the matrix itself appears in the middle and, by default, an â€˜associated viewâ€™ appears on the right. This view, as the name suggestions, shows content associated with the framework matrix.

You can change what precise content is displayed by clicking the â€˜Associated Viewâ€™ button on the Ribbon Bar. (If it is not visible, click inside a framework matrix cell first.)

Row Coding - show all content coded by the case the row is for.
Cell Coding - show all content coded by the row case AND the column code.
Summary Links - show only content whether a summary link has been made between text in the cell and the associated view.


Similarly, what gets highlighted in the Associated View can be changed by clicking the â€˜Highlightâ€™ button on the Ribbon bar.

None - turn off highlighting.
Column Coding - highlight everything in the Associated View coded at the code for the currently selected column.
Summary Links - highlight text in the Associated View that has a summary link with text in the currently selected cell.
Summary Links from Position - highlight text in the Associated View that has a summary link with text for where the tex cursor is currently within the selected cell.
Auto Scroll - a useful option to turn on, when on if you click text in the cell that has a summary link, the Associated View will immediately scroll to where the linked text is within the Associated View.



Summary Links

To create a summary link:

Select text within a Framework Matrix cell (highlighted in blue).
Select text within the Associated View (highlighted in black).
Click the â€˜New Summary Linkâ€™ button in the Ribbon bar.

title: Building Themes
text:
Reusable Cells
Something not immediately clear when using Framework Matrices is that the cells actually exist independently of any given matrix. Behind the scenes each cells is stored by on its intersection, the case and code combination it relates to. A cell then will appear in all framework matrices which has that case and code.
After adding some text to cells in the â€˜ANY OTHER COMMENTSâ€™ and â€˜INTRODUCTIONâ€™ columns - even if just gibberish:

Create a new Framework Matrix.
For rows use the cases in the â€˜Remain Interview Participantsâ€™ dynamic set.
For columns select only the â€˜ANY OTHER COMMENTSâ€™ and â€™INTRODUCTIONâ€™codes.

This makes cells within Framework Matrices â€˜composableâ€™, you can make various larger and smaller matrices based on particular analysis aims without risking losing text or accidentally duplicating work.

title: Building Themes
text:
Re-Casing
One limitation with Framework Matrices is that Rows must be cases and Columns codes. However, this is another situation where dynamic sets and queries can come to the rescue.
First:

Create a new Coding Query
For criteria, â€˜Coded toâ€™, â€˜Any Selected Code or Caseâ€™, in the â€˜Remain Interview Participantsâ€™ dynamic set.
â€˜Save Criteriaâ€¦â€™ as Sections Coded at Remain Interview Participants.
Click wee triangle next to â€˜Run Queryâ€™ and select â€˜Run and Save Resultsâ€™
In the Store Query Results dialogue on the Location row, click â€˜Selectâ€¦â€™
Select the â€˜Casesâ€™ folder as the location and hit â€˜OKâ€™
Give it a suitable name, such as â€œRemain Supportersâ€
Hit â€˜OKâ€™.

Then:

Create a new dynamic folder â€˜Leave Interview Participantsâ€™ with criteria â€˜Codeâ€™, â€˜That Codesâ€™, any items in the â€˜Interviews (2016)â€™ folder.
Create (and save) a new Coding Query, â€˜Coded toâ€™, â€˜Any Selected Code or Caseâ€™, in the â€˜Leave Interview Participantsâ€™ dynamic set.
â€˜Run and Save Resultsâ€™ to a new case in the â€˜Casesâ€™ folder, â€œLeave Supportersâ€

Finally:

Create a new Framework Matrix
Rows = â€œRemain Supportersâ€ and â€œLeave Supportersâ€
Columns = â€œAutocoded (Sections)â€

Another example: 1. Create a new Framework Matrix 2. Rows, first add all individual cases from the â€˜Remain Interview Participantsâ€™ dynamic set. 3. Rows, second add the â€˜Remain Supportersâ€™ case. 4. Columns = â€œAutocoded (Sections)â€
This then provides a Framework Matrix with a row for each Remain supporting participant, and a row for summarising across all Remain supporters.

title: Saving and sharing
text:
Saving the project
If you followed the default settings, we will have seen pop-ups every 15 minutes to ask us to save.


To remind yourself where the file is saved you can go to:
File > Project Properties > General
and look at the location under File Name:





If you click on the â€˜save and recoveryâ€™ tab you can alter the frequency of saving.
You also get the chance to set up a recovery option. This can be helpful if you are experiencing issues with Nvivo crashing.





Sharing with others






ğŸ¤¢ Itâ€™s not you, itâ€™s NVivo



Remember: NVivo only has â€˜forwards compatabilityâ€™ between different versions.
If a project was created in NVivo 14 and someone was to open it in NVivo 15, they will be prompted to convert it to an NVivo 15 project file. However, once converted to an NVivo 15 compatable project file, it will no longer be possible to open it in NVivo 14. It is essential then that when collaborating with others that you are all using the same version of NVivo.


You can easily email or share the project (.nvp file) with others using the same version of NVivo.
If you want to share with a mac user, you also need to convert it before you share it.


To do this, open the file tab -> Copy project





Copy to, Nvivo (Mac), and choose a save location.



The conversion to mac and vice versa may take some time.
After the conversion is complete, you should have created a duplicate mac version fo the file in .nvpx format.
More information here.

title: Open coding
text:
What is open coding?
â€˜Open codingâ€™ refers to inductive forms of coding, where meaning emerges from the data through the researcher engaging with the content and deciding to create a code.
Codes are not pre-defined; they emerge through the analysis.






ğŸ¤” Critical Considerations



Before jumping into open coding, letâ€™s consider:

what themes we might expect to emerge from this dataset?

what kinds of phenomena might be want to capture with open coding?





Coding based on attitudes/emotions
We know there are likely to be strong opinions expressed, so letâ€™s set up some attitude codes that we can quickly apply while reading the interviews:


Create a new parent code by either 1) selecting Create->code on the top ribbon or 2) right- clicking in the open space under the codes and selecting â€˜new codeâ€™:





Give this new code the title â€˜Attitudeâ€™ (1), give it a rich description (remember your future self) (2),
Do not â€˜aggregate coding from childrenâ€™ for the attitude parent code (3), as we would seldom search for something including everything coded at any type of attitude. This can be toggled on later if needed, though.



Next, we want to create sub-codes within â€˜Attitudeâ€™ for:

Mixed
Negative
Neutral
Positive



To create a sub-code right-click an existing code and select â€˜new codeâ€™:



You can see you now have a basic set of attitude codes to code to as you read the transcripts:



Create new code based on ideas emerging in the data
As you read, you may start to notice a key theme/idea/concept popping up throughout that doesnâ€™t fit into an attitude that you have pre-defined. You may decide that this deserves its own new code. For example, the theme of â€˜immigrationâ€™ emerges repeatedly


Create a new code for this in the same way as beforeâ€¦




Practice open coding


Spend some time open coding by reading thorough the interviews in the 2016 interview folder.
As you go along, code to existing codes or make new ones for recurring ideas. Donâ€™t worry about going back and coding something that might not have occurred to you earlier in the interview or in previous interviews.



Remember that coding is iterative! and the same piece of text can have MULTIPLE CODES.



Reflexive coding






ğŸ¤” Critical Considerations



After reading a few interviews, take a break to revisit your codes.

Are there any common themes that might make a good â€˜parent codeâ€™?
is there something that stands out in your mind from reading that you donâ€™t see in your coding?




Donâ€™t be afraid to re-code the same section with more than one thing (e.g.Â you might code one comment as â€˜trustâ€™, â€˜Labour Partyâ€™, and â€˜positiveâ€™).
Donâ€™t be afraid to make mistakes â€“ you can always un-code!

title: Checking your work
text:
View material within each code


Double click on a code to view the material that has been coded. This aggregates information across multiple files and transcripts.


Here is an example of seeing all material with the â€˜economyâ€™ code:



Coding stripes

To see what you have (and havenâ€™t) coded already, you can turn on coding stripes, which visualize the amount of text in the transcript coded against different codes. You may find that youâ€™ve coded some areas mistakenly or missed other codes


The transcript now has vertical lines on the far right. These indicate the parts of the transcript which are coded to cases and codes. The colour codes are set automatically but you can manually adjust this by editing the code settings.

title: Welcome!
text:
Session Brief



This one-day in-person workshop is aimed at those with no experience of Nvivo, or those who would like a refresher. We will move through three topics:

The morning is led by Dr Katy Keenan will work through some basic tasks:

setting up a new Nvivo project
organising materials
creating cases and case classifications
manual coding
some autocoding features

The afternoon is led by Alasdair Stewart and will move to more advanced features and the flexible ways these can be used for qualitative analysis.
Students will learn how to use some more advanced features of NVivo:

coding workflows, tip and tricks
different types of queries
framework matrices

We will use some curated open access qualitative data (the Qualitative Election Study of Britain). However, there is an opportunity to discuss how to use NVivo to manage your own project.

title: Welcome!
text:
Session Aims






ğŸ¤” Critical Considerations



The sections and tasks for this workshop session are based around problems and considerations to make that you might encounter as your analysis progresses.
With each we will cover some conceptual points and a follow along demonstration that combines various NVivo features together to achieve an analysis aim.
The purpose of this is to explain features in context, the how and why you would want to use them, rather than just providing an abstract technical explanation of what they do.
Importantly, after the follow along demonstrations, we will have time for experimentation and discussion. I have tried to identify common enough problems and considerations that will be encountered across different types of project. However, all the steps and features covered can be combined and deployed in a multitude of ways. Please use the â€˜experiment and discussâ€™ sections to raise any questions about how what we are covering could be applied to your project or recombined for other analysis aims.








ğŸ§Ÿ Slaying QDAS Zombies



To say some qualitative researchers were initially resistant to qualitative data analysis software is an understatement. Early literature on the value of computing to qualitative analysis was filled with acerbic critiques, seeing software as undermining the rich in-depth analysis that qualitative analysis offers.
There was a partial truth to these criticisms as the nascent software was minimal in features and capabilities. What some critiques got wrong - or, at least, gave the impression of - though, was taking the limitations of the software as it was and treating these as inherent and inescapable.
The big four critiques - that software distances researchers from data by placing a barrier between them, strips qualitative methods of its diversity by homogenising coding and analysis, replaces the creativity of qualitative analysis with mechnical steps, and dehumanises participants by decontextualising their experiences - are not unavoidable dangers with modern software.
However, the critiques unfortunately still persist as QDAS Zombies by being recounted again and again in the literature reviews of journal articles and books. That QDAS software is not overly friendly to new users - see below - unfortunately also keeps the zombie critiques going. When users struggle so much with the software that they find themselves turning to paper and pen â€“ or copying chunks of text into Word/Excel files â€“ itâ€™s no wonder these critiques feel more alive than dead.
What we will cover in this workshop should go towards dispelling that feeling by demystifying the features that help solve common problems and analysis aims beyond the basics. Iâ€™d go as far as arguing that once you gain a greater understanding and confidence in using contemporary qualitative analysis software, the zombie critiques are a greater risk when using paper and pen.








ğŸ¤¢ Itâ€™s not you, itâ€™s NVivo



NVivo is powerful and without a doubt better than analogue paper and pen analysis â€“ or worse, copying and pasting chunks of text into multiple Word/Excel files â€“ but it remains far from perfect. It is needlessly bloated and clunky, and historically had a reputation for regularly crashing.
The unintuitive design and labyrinthine steps required for some tasks â€“ never mind the joys of trying to recall them each time when first starting â€“ gives the false impression that it is all overly-complex. It might not seem it now, but with perseverance the pieces start fitting together, and the initial overwhelm will dissipate into mild frustrations.
To Lumiveroâ€™s credit, the rate at which NVivo crashes has vastly reduced and is no longer a daily occurrence. However, it can still throw up the occasional unexpected error, freeze and lock-up, or decide to crash and die completely. This is most often â€˜NVivo-errorâ€™ not â€˜user-errorâ€™ â€“ there was not anything wrong in how you set up your project or actions you were doing, itâ€™s just NVivo being NVivo.

title: Organisation Codes
text:
Adding Organisation Codes


Go to the main â€˜Codesâ€™ folder.
Right-click on any white space and select â€˜New Codeâ€¦â€™



Provide it with a suitable name, such as â€˜Organisation Codesâ€™
I have added â€œz - â€¦â€ at the start as that ensure itâ€™s placed at the end when alphabetically ordered.



Drag and drop the existing â€˜quotable quoteâ€™ code to become a child code of â€˜z - Organisation Codesâ€™.
(Optional) rename it to â€˜Goldâ€™.
Create another two child codes â€˜Unsureâ€™ and â€˜Exampleâ€™.







Different organisation codes




There are various different codes researchers make to to help with organising their coding. A few examples:

Example - Use for coding sections that are serve as illustrative example of another code.
Gold - Use for coding sections that have high probability of later being used as a quote. (Though ensure to avoid cherry-picking!)
Important - Use for coding sections that are important for the analysis. (This can be distinct in many cases from â€˜Goldâ€™.)
Unsure - Use for coding sections that are coded to another code, but you are unsure whether either it is right code for the section or this coded section is making you question the overall code.

IMPORTANT - You do not need all of these! This is merely showing range of examples. Which and how many to have wil change based on personal preferences and analysis aims. For example, when working as part of a large team, â€˜exampleâ€™ can be useful for researchers to identify coded sections they think illustrate specific codes they are developing. This can then help inform discussion to agree a share coding schema for the project.

Another way to use codes for organising is having codes to store excerpts you intend to use / have used in specific articles or thesis chapters. This can be combined with queries as well to aid finding most relevant sections. For example, a Matrix Coding Query with your writing organisation codes with your main coding schema.
Due to the much more niche use-case for these codes, they are definitely ones to chuck in their own folder to avoid cluttering the top-level folder.



Code Matrix Query
First:

Select two or three existing codes from the top-level Codes folder or â€˜Autocoded (Theme)â€™ sub-folder.
Open tabs for to view the code results for each.
Quickly go through coding sections from the code results to â€˜Exampleâ€™, â€˜Goldâ€™, and â€˜Unsureâ€™.



Go to the Query Criteria folder
Right-click and select New Query
and, Matrix Coding Query



Rows = the regular codes you chose.
Columns = Gold, Unsure, and Example.
Hit â€˜Run Queryâ€™
Remember to also â€˜Save Criteriaâ€¦â€™

This will then produce a coding matrix you can then use to find sections coded at both a regular and organisation code.

title: Organisation Codes
text:
Memo Links

Create a linked memo for one of your chosen regular codes:

Right-click the code.
Select â€˜Memo Linkâ€™.
Then â€˜Link to New Memoâ€¦â€™


Provide an appropriate name. For memos linked to codes I tend to go with â€œm - Code Nameâ€ naming convention.


Add headers for â€˜Exampleâ€™, â€˜Goldâ€™,â€™ Unsureâ€™.

You can then use the coding matrix results to read through content coded to both the code and the three organisation nodes. (Or, for time, add some lorem ipsum.)

Memo See Also Links
It is possible to link text within a file to text within a memo.


Select the text you want to link to the memo text.
Right-click and select â€˜Copyâ€™.


Back in the memo:

Select the memo text you want to be linked.
Right-click and select â€˜Paste as See-Also Linkâ€™.


See also links appear in red highlighting and, similar to Annotations, a panel listing all See-Also Links within the current tab can be displayed at the bottom of the page.

Importantly, if you right-click red highlighted text or any of the items listed in the See-Also Links panel, you can â€˜Open To Itemâ€™. This will open a new tab for the file that contains the linked text, and will auto-scroll to the exact section the linked text appears.


Autocode Memos
As an example of how flexible some of NVivos tools are, as with files, it is possible to autocode memos.


Right-click the memo you created.
Select â€˜Autocodeâ€¦â€™






Change â€˜Underâ€™ to â€˜New Folderâ€™
Provide it an appropriate Name
Hit â€˜Finishâ€™


This may not seem like much with just a single memo, but if you had a series of structure memos this would let you quickly find and navigate them by specific sections.

title: Organisation Codes
text:
Static Sets
Going through the â€˜Unsureâ€™ sections, for example, may help you identify new code to create or ones to replace.
Say you decided to create three new codes to outright replace three old ones, but this is made tricky as the each code does replace one code, but instead cuts across content in 2-3 of the old codes.
This is where static sets come in handy.

Add three existing Codes to the static set.
Within your â€˜Codesâ€™ top-level folder create three new codes of your choice, for simplicity Iâ€™m just going with â€˜Aâ€™, â€˜Bâ€™, â€˜Câ€™.
Add these to the â€˜New Codesâ€™ static set.


Coded to Old Codes, but not New Codes


Create a new Matrix Coding Query.
Rows = â€˜Old Codesâ€™ static set.
Columns = â€˜New Codesâ€™ static set.
Change â€˜Coding at rows â€¦ columnsâ€™ to Not.
â€˜Run Queryâ€™

This will create a single cell, double-clicking will open a coding results tab with all sections coded at the codes in the â€˜Old Codesâ€™ static set.
You can now work your way recoding to the New Codes. Importantly, during recoding you can hit â€˜Run Queryâ€™ and get an update of how many sections are left to recode. This can be extremely useful you whilst recoding you realise you actually need a fourth new code â€˜Dâ€™. You can create it, add it to â€˜New Codesâ€™ static set and â€˜Run Queryâ€™ for your â€˜Recoding Old with Newâ€™ Matrix Code Query.

Remember you can change the â€˜coding contentâ€™ to view more text surrounding the sections coded to your old codes. That wonâ€™t make a difference for most of the codes in this project file, but if you only coded sentences or even short phrases, this will add back some additional context.

Similarly, you can turn on coding stripes and highlighting using the static set as a filter.

This can save a lot of headaches and frustration when if adopting a coding approach that have multiple stages in developing and refinding your codes or working on a large project with multiple researchers coding across different policy areas where you have a lot of codes across multiple folders that you may want retrieve quickly.


Other uses for static sets

Grouping conceptual related codes outside your main coding schema.
Collating a mix of items (files, cases, codes) that are pertinent to an aspect of your analysis.
Making a group of participants with similar experiences, but where it would not necessarily make sense to capture it using Attributes.

title: Summary
text:
These examples show different ways you can iteratively build upon your project structure as your analysis progresses.

Your initial structure (folders, codes, cases) can be used to create dynamic sets or query for specific coded sections.
It is possible to add layers upon layers. A dynamic set can be used as part of a query - saving you having to repeat the specific criteria for it again and again.

It can be useful then, in addition to considering your â€˜foundationalâ€™ structure to think about which dynamic sets can add a supporting additional layer to make other tasks easier in the long-term.
It can feel slow and clunky at first getting to grips with creating them, but as you create more your pace will quicken, and through combining them with queries start to more intuitively combine NVivo features in relation to questions that arise during analysis.







Donâ€™t panic!



It is not a problem if you have already started your analysis and not added some of the ways to structure a project file covered in this session.

Most - such as auto-coding and creating folders - can be created at any stage.
Not every project and analysis needs to use all of these structuring options. Some options also add equivalent structure in different ways, where there is some â€˜aesthetic choiceâ€™ in which to use.
If your transcripts do not make use of headers to structure the main topics covered, you can still do manual â€˜broad-brushâ€™ coding. (If having this topic-level coding would benefit your analysis!)

Importantly, for some project structure decisions there is no 100% right/wrong way to do it.
In the example covered we had a â€˜Participantsâ€™ case folder, containing the cases for all participants, and used a dynamic set to get â€˜Interview Participantsâ€™.
Another project structure may have case folders for â€˜Interview participantsâ€™ and â€˜Focus Group participants, and use a dynamic set to get â€™All Participantsâ€™.
Note, this would be feasible as long as the interview and focus group participants are two distinct groups. If some participants took part in both interviews and focus groups, then it would not be possible to have separate Cases folders for them, and the project would need to be structured similar to this example.

title: Compare Groups
text:
Our final intial question was making an inital broad comparison between the views of Leave and Remain supporters.
We can achieve this with a Matrix Coding Query combining our interview transcript autocoding with are People case classification attribute values.


Within the Query Criteria, right-click in the white space and -



Select â€˜New Queryâ€™
Then â€˜Matrix Coding Queryâ€™


This will open a new tab for creating a Matrix Coding Query. We can see some of the familar elements again. In yellow we have the optiosn for searching across all Files & Externals or specific Items and Folders. In blue, we have the default â€˜Andâ€™ for handling criteria - other options include Or, Not, and Near. What is different though is rather than adding 1+ criteria, we have a box for selecting Rows and another for Columns, in red.






It is possible to drag and drop items into the boxes for Rows and Columns, but it is often far quicker and more convenient to use the â€˜Select Project Itemsâ€™ dialogue.



Click the â€˜+â€™ underneath the Rows box on the left.
From the two options click â€˜Select Itemsâ€¦â€™


Then within the Select Project Items dialogue:



Expand the Codes folder.
Check the tickbox for the â€˜Autocoded (Sections)â€™ sub-folder.
Hit â€˜OKâ€™.





We can follow the same process to select our columns.



Click the â€˜+â€™ underneath the Columns box.
From the two options click â€˜Select Itemsâ€¦â€™


Whilst â€˜Select Attribute Values..â€™ is an option, that is for selecting individual values with criteria (equals, does not equal) one by one. For our purposes, â€˜Select Itemsâ€¦â€™ remains more convenient.



Select the â€˜Case Classificationsâ€™ folder.
Expand the â€˜Peopleâ€™ case classification.
Expand the â€˜2016 voteâ€™ attribute.


After scrolling down a bit:



Check the box for â€˜Leaveâ€™ attribute value.
Check the box for â€˜Remainâ€™ attribute value.
Hit â€˜OKâ€™.





After selecting our Rows and Columns, we can hit â€˜Run Queryâ€™ (in pink) to create our Coding Matrix. Remember if you want to be able to quickly re-run and update the Coding Matrix to also hit â€˜Save Criteriaâ€¦â€™ (in green) and give it a suitable name.
The Coding Matrix itself (in blue) for each cell in the table shows how many coded sections intersect the two. So, the cell highlight (in yellow) is telling us that 15 sections coded â€˜VOTING DECISIONâ€™ were also coded to cases, where the participant the case is for supported Leave (both in red).






That may not seem all that impressive at first. The real power of Coding Matrices though come from double-clicking any of the cells.
That will open a new tab showing all the coded sections being counted in that cell. So, for our example, it opens a tab showing all sections coded â€˜VOTING DECISIONâ€™ AND also coded to a case where the participant supported Leave.
This makes a Coding Matrix the equivalent of a table of shortcuts to more specific queries. Since you can create them with classification attributes, it also makes them ideal for creating queries to aid comparison.

title: Adding Organisation Codes
text:
What are â€˜organisationâ€™ codes?
Organisation codes are various different codes that are not part of the main â€˜thematicâ€™ coding, but that researchers create to to help with organising their coding.
A few examples:

Example - Use for coding sections that are serve as illustrative example of another code.
Gold - Use for coding sections that have high probability of later being used as a quote. (Though ensure to avoid cherry-picking!)
Important - Use for coding sections that are important for the analysis. (This can be distinct in many cases from â€˜Goldâ€™.)
Unsure - Use for coding sections that are coded to another code, but you are unsure whether either it is right code for the section or this coded section is making you question the overall code.


IMPORTANT - You do not need all of these! This is merely showing range of examples. Which and how many to have wil change based on personal preferences and analysis aims. For example, when working as part of a large team, â€˜exampleâ€™ can be useful for researchers to identify coded sections they think illustrate specific codes they are developing. This can then help inform discussion to agree a share coding schema for the project.


Creating Organisation Codes


Go to the main â€˜Codesâ€™ folder.
Right-click on any white space and select â€˜New Codeâ€¦â€™





Provide it with a suitable name, such as â€˜Organisation Codesâ€™
I have added â€œz - â€¦â€ at the start as that ensure itâ€™s placed at the end when alphabetically ordered.





Drag and drop the existing â€˜quotable quoteâ€™ code to become a child code of â€˜z - Organisation Codesâ€™.
(Optional) rename it to â€˜Goldâ€™.
Create another two child codes â€˜Unsureâ€™ and â€˜Exampleâ€™.





Other Types of Organisation Codes
Another way to use codes for organising is having codes to store excerpts you intend to use / have used in specific articles or thesis chapters. This can be combined with queries as well to aid finding most relevant sections. For example, a Matrix Coding Query - which we will cover next - with your writing organisation codes with your main coding schema.

Due to the much more niche use-case for these codes, they are definitely ones to chuck in their own folder to avoid cluttering the top-level folder.

title: Viewing a Framework Matrix
text:
When viewing a framework matrix, the matrix itself appears in the middle and, by default, an â€˜Associated Viewâ€™ appears on the right. This view, as the name suggestions, shows content associated with the framework matrix.
You can change what precise content is displayed by clicking the â€˜Associated Viewâ€™ button on the Ribbon Bar. (If it is not visible, click inside a framework matrix cell first.)

There are three options for what content to show:

Row Coding - show all content coded by the case the row is for.
Cell Coding - show all content coded by the row case AND the column code.
Summary Links - show only content whether a summary link has been made between text in the cell and the associated view.

Similarly, what gets highlighted in the Associated View can be changed by clicking the â€˜Highlightâ€™ button on the Ribbon bar.

The options here are:

None - turn off highlighting.
Column Coding - highlight everything in the Associated View coded at the code for the currently selected column.
Summary Links - highlight text in the Associated View that has a summary link with text in the currently selected cell.
Summary Links from Position - highlight text in the Associated View that has a summary link with text for where the tex cursor is currently within the selected cell.

Finally, a useful option to turn-on before we move to the next page:

Auto Scroll - when on if you click text in the cell that has a summary link, the Associated View will immediately scroll to where the linked text is within the Associated View.


Before clicking to go to the â€˜Summary Linksâ€™ page, ensure â€˜Auto Scrollâ€™ is turned-on.

title: Welcome!
text:
Session Brief



This one-day in-person workshop is designed for those with a basic working knowledge of NVivo for qualitative research projects. It is designed to introduce you to more advanced features and the flexible ways these can be used for qualitative analysis. It is designed as a follow-on from the â€œIntroduction to Qualitative Analysis Projects in NVivoâ€, but is open to everyone regardless of whether they attended that session.
Students will learn how to use some more advanced features of NVivo:

coding workflows, tip and tricks
using static and dynamic sets
different types of queries
framework matrices

We will use some curated open access qualitative data (the Qualitative Election Study of Britain). However, there is an opportunity to discuss how to use NVivo to manage your own project.

title: Welcome!
text:
Session Aims

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ“ NVivo 201 - Additive Analysis
This workshop covers intermediate-advanced topics in using NVivo for qualitative data analysis. Key to how the more advanced features are introduced is through considering them as flexible tools for â€˜additive analysisâ€™. They add to the â€˜foundationalâ€™ elements of your project â€“ your files, folders, nodes, cases, and notes â€“ providing ways to retrieve, review, and recontextualise data based on the aims of your analysis. They are part of the extended toolset for crafting various ways to organise, navigate, layer, and weave your analysis and data.
It is assumed, therefore, that you have pre-requisite knowledge in how to create and set up an NVivo project file, including importing data, auto-coding by speaker / structure, creating nodes and cases, and doing basic coding.
A Project File though is provided with these already set up, and the follow along demonstrations will give a partial refresher on some of these. We can also use the experiment and discussion sections to do a short review of any of them.


ğŸ¤” Problem-based approach
The sections and tasks for this workshop session are based around problems and considerations to make that you might encounter as your analysis progresses.
With each we will cover some conceptual points and a follow along demonstration that combines various NVivo features together to achieve an analysis aim.
The purpose of this is to explain features in context, the how and why you would want to use them, rather than just providing an abstract technical explanation of what they do.
Importantly, after the follow along demonstrations, we will have time for experimentation and discussion. I have tried to identify common enough problems and considerations that will be encountered across different types of project. However, all the steps and features covered can be combined and deployed in a multitude of ways. Please use the â€˜experiment and discussâ€™ sections to raise any questions about how what we are covering could be applied to your project or recombined for other analysis aims.






â€˜Living Documentsâ€™



These pages are â€˜living documentsâ€™, they will continually and iteratively be updated over time. Please see the Callout on the About page




ğŸ§Ÿ Slaying QDAS zombies
To say some qualitative researchers were initially resistant to qualitative data analysis software is an understatement. Early literature on the value of computing to qualitative analysis was filled with acerbic critiques, seeing software as undermining the rich in-depth analysis that qualitative analysis offers.
There was a partial truth to these criticisms as the nascent software was minimal in features and capabilities. What some critiques got wrong - or, at least, gave the impression of - though, was taking the limitations of the software as it was and treating these as inherent and inescapable.
The big four critiques - that software distances researchers from data by placing a barrier between them, strips qualitative methods of its diversity by homogenising coding and analysis, replaces the creativity of qualitative analysis with mechnical steps, and dehumanises participants by decontextualising their experiences - are not unavoidable dangers with modern software.
However, the critiques unfortunately still persist as QDAS Zombies by being recounted again and again in the literature reviews of journal articles and books. That QDAS software is not overly friendly to new users - see below - unfortunately also keeps the zombie critiques going. When users struggle so much with the software that they find themselves turning to paper and pen â€“ or copying chunks of text into Word/Excel files â€“ itâ€™s no wonder these critiques feel more alive than dead.
What we will cover in this workshop should go towards dispelling that feeling by demystifying the features that help solve common problems and analysis aims beyond the basics. Iâ€™d go as far as arguing that once you gain a greater understanding and confidence in using contemporary qualitative analysis software, the zombie critiques are a greater risk when using paper and pen.


ğŸ¤¢ Itâ€™s not you, itâ€™s NVivo!
NVivo is powerful and without a doubt better than analogue paper and pen analysis â€“ or worse, copying and pasting chunks of text into multiple Word/Excel files â€“ but it remains far from perfect. It is needlessly bloated and clunky, and historically had a reputation for regularly crashing.
The unintuitive design and labyrinthine steps required for some tasks â€“ never mind the joys of trying to recall them each time when first starting â€“ gives the false impression that it is all overly-complex. It might not seem it now, but with perseverance the pieces start fitting together, and the initial overwhelm will dissipate into mild frustrations.
To Lumiveroâ€™s credit, the rate at which NVivo crashes has vastly reduced and is no longer a daily occurrence. However, it can still throw up the occasional unexpected error, freeze and lock-up, or decide to crash and die completely. This is most often â€˜NVivo-errorâ€™ not â€˜user-errorâ€™ â€“ there was not anything wrong in how you set up your project or actions you were doing, itâ€™s just NVivo being NVivo.

title: Project File
text: An NVivo project file for this workshop is available to download from the â€˜NVivo Training 2024/25â€™ group on Social.

title: Project File
text:
The Data Set
The NVivo project file uses data from focus groups and interviews conducted in 2015 and 2016 as part of the Qualitative Election Study of Britain.

The QESB is a collaborative effort between researchers from the UWE Bristol, the University of Dundee, and GESIS in Germany. Since our launch in 2010, our aim has been to learn about the thoughts, feelings, and opinions of every day voters, before and after the UK general election. To this end, we hold focus groups and interviews, online and in-person. During this general election period, we want to hear your thoughts on political life in the UK. Whether itâ€™s about the election, political leaders, parties, economic concerns, the NHS, or climate change, we want to hear it all.

The data is open access and available from the UK Data Service.
For more information on open research and data: - The FAIR principles to improve the findability, accessibility, interoperability, and reuse of digital assets. - UK Data Service hub for archiving qualitative data and secondary analysis. - UK Data Service hub for data skills modules, covering research data management, data for reuse, and more.
Important to making data open access is storing it in â€˜interoperableâ€™, and ideally â€˜open standardâ€™, formats. Interoperable means that the files are not restricted to being opened by a specific single application. An open standard is one that is available for anyone to use, share, or access.
Full â€˜open researchâ€™ remains limited within qualitative research for various reasons. Importantly, whilst there is an open QDPX format for sharing qualitative data analysis projects, it is a â€˜lossyâ€™ format â€“ where folder structures and more are lost when exporting to the open format.
In order then to avoid losing time creating an NVivo project file from scratch / tidying up an imported QDPX file, an NVivo project file has been set up for the workshop and available from Social. This project file is similar to what you would have had at the end of the Intro to NVivo workshop with a few minor tweaks.

title: Project File
text:
Downloading the NVivo Project File
From the group page, to access the file:

Download linkZip file



Click â€˜Feedâ€™ in the group navigation bar.

Scroll down the Feed to find my post with the OneDrive link and click it.
 ../ A new tab should open with a button to click to â€˜Downloadâ€™ the file.






Fail-safe



In case the download link is not working (my university seems to randomly stop share links from working), there is a zip file containing the NVivo project file on Social as well. Use the next tab for instructions to download and extract the zip file.





Click â€˜Documentsâ€™ in the group navigation bar.

Select the â€˜Going Further (Feb 2025)â€™ folder.


Click the three dots to open the pop-up menu.
Click â€˜Downloadâ€™ and choose a suitable location to save the file on your device.



From the folder you downloaded it to, right-click on the zip file.
Select â€˜Extract Allâ€¦â€™



Click â€˜Extractâ€™ from the dialogue window and a new folder will be created containing the NVivo project file.

title: Project File
text:
Converting/Upgrading the Project
NVivo project files are â€˜forwardsâ€™ but not â€˜backwardsâ€™ compatible. This means that newer versions of NVivo can open project files created in older versions, but not vice versa.
Due to that, the project file provided was created in NVivo 12, which was the oldest version attendees said they were using in the sign-up survey.
If you are using NVivo 12, you can open the file and directly start working in it.
If you are using a newer version of NVivo or NVivo for MacOS, you will be greeted by a screen asking you to convert/upgrade the file:

Upgrade




(Optional) click â€˜Browseâ€¦â€™ to choose location to save and rename the project file.
Click â€˜Nextâ€™.



From the next screen, hit â€˜Upgradeâ€™ to confirm and start the upgrade. Once complete NVivo will open the file automatically.










NVivo Version Differences



On Windows, there are not any overly significant changes in features from NVivo 12 onwards. The main changes are cosmetic, menu options, and naming conventions.
NVivo for MacOS has always had a different look and menu options. It now has most of the same main features, though a few sub-features remain absent.
Weâ€™ll cover some of these differences as we go. The Resources page also has links to the NVivo User Help Pages for different versions.

title: Project File
text:
Project File Overview
As a (very) quick overview of the project file:

Files

Data > Files


Focus Groups (2015): Transcripts from three pre-general election focus groups from 2015.
Interviews (2016): Fourteen telephone interviews on the EU Referendum in 2016.
Literature: Containing two articles by QESB team members, one on using grounded theory, the other on using focus groups.
Project Files: With files that contain additional information about the project, the research phases, and participants who took part.




Codes

Coding > Codes


Codes: Top-level folder with some initial coding created during the Intro to NVivo workshop.

Autocoded (Sections): Sub-folder with the broad-brush themes that were created auto-coding the Headings within the interview transcripts.
Autocoded (Themes): Sub-folder with codes created by auto-coding â€˜themesâ€™.









Warning



We have â€œautocoded themesâ€ within this document merely to provide a broad range of example codes to work with in the exercises. However, in practice, do not rely on such autocoding instead of creating and coding with your own codes.




Cases

Cases > Cases


Interviewer: Cases created when â€˜autocoding by speakerâ€™ that code transcript sections where an interviewer / moderator from the research team is speaking.
Participants: Cases created when â€˜autocoding by speakerâ€™ that code transcript sections where participants are speaking.
Case Classifications: Top-level folder contains the case classifications and their attributes. For this project, there is only one case classification - â€˜Peopleâ€™.

People: Sub-folder with all cases classified as â€˜Peopleâ€™, where can see the attributes for specific participants. (Note - the interviewer cases are also classified as people, in many cases you would want to remove from the same classification as participants.)





Notes



Memos: NVivoâ€™s built-in note-taking system. Contains a few existing memos with further project info and reflectives on initial analysis.
Framework Matrices: Create summaries for cases by node. Currently, empty.
Annotations: Annotations added to files, with couple examples.
See-Also Links: Use to link content/files to other content/files. Currently, empty.




Sets



Static Sets: Manually created collections of project items, of any type. Think of this as a way to group and organise items for specific tasks without changing their primary structure. For example, a code can only exist within a single folder within the â€œCoding > Codesâ€ section. However, it can be included within an unlimited number of static sets.
Dynamic Sets: Collections of project items created based on search criteria. As they are criteria based they also auto-update based on any changes in your project. For example, if you had a dynamic set for all codes used to code focus group transcripts, each time you use a new code when coding the focus groups, it will automatically then be included in the dynamic set.








NVivo 12 - â€˜search foldersâ€™



Dynamic Sets are a new name given to what were called â€˜search foldersâ€™ in NVivo 12. They operate exactly the same, all that is different is the name.




Queries



Query Criteria: Location to store saved queries, saving you from having to manually put them together each time.
Query Results: Location to store query results. This can be useful for more complex queries that take a long-time to process to save having to re-run it every time â€“ just remember it wonâ€™t reflect any changes to your project file. Query results can also be used to create new nodes and cases.
Coding Matrices: Similar to the above but for the results of a coding matrix. By default manually created coding matrices saved results with be in Query Results, but they can manually moved across. Coding matrices automatically produced, such as when autocoding by theme, are stored here by default.

title: Memo Links
text:
Memos in NVivo
Memos within NVivo as basically rich-text files contained within your project file. They can be used for various purposes, such as storing additional project information, a log of analysis plans and what has been completed so far, and so on. One key use is to use them to store reflections about your coding. Importantly, it is possible to â€˜linkâ€™ memos to any other object within NVivo, such as transcripts, cases, and codes. This means for each code you can create a link memo for it that can use to make reflexive notes as you code.


Creating Memo Links
Create a linked memo for one of your chosen thematic codes:


Right-click the code.
Select â€˜Memo Linkâ€™.
Then â€˜Link to New Memoâ€¦â€™




Provide an appropriate name. For memos linked to codes I tend to go with â€œm - Code Nameâ€ naming convention.




Add headers for â€˜Exampleâ€™, â€˜Goldâ€™,â€™ Unsureâ€™.





Combining Features
Now, you can use the coding matrix results we previously created to quickly find and read through content coded to both the code and these three organisation nodes. (Or, for time, add some lorem ipsum.)
This shows the power of NVivo that comes from â€˜combining featuresâ€™ into a workflow which may not be obvious and intuitive at first, but once you have a general sense of the features you will start to see various ways they can be combined for different stages and aims of your analysis.

title: Summary Links
text:
What are â€˜Summary Links?â€™
Summary links are a framework matrix equivalent to memo see-also links. A summary link links text within a framework matrix cell to text within the transcript it is summarises from.


Creating a Summary Link
Fortunately, the process for creating a summary link is more straight-forward and easier to remember than creating memo see-also links.
To create a summary link:


Select text within a Framework Matrix cell (highlighted in blue).
Select text within the Associated View (highlighted in black).
Click the â€˜New Summary Linkâ€™ button in the Ribbon bar.





Navigating with Summary Links
Now try:


Change the â€˜Associated Viewâ€™ to â€˜Cell Codingâ€™.
For one of the participants, write some quick summary text in two of the cells and create summary links between the text in the cell and the transcript.
Change the â€˜Associated Viewâ€™ to â€˜Row Codingâ€™.
Within the cells click any of the text highlighted red (meaning it has a summary link) and the transcript will auto-scroll to the relevant section.

title: Reusable Cells
text:
Something not immediately clear when using Framework Matrices is that the cells actually exist independently of any given matrix. Behind the scenes each cells is stored by on its intersection, the case and code combination it relates to. A cell then will appear in all framework matrices which has that case and code.
After adding some text to cells in the â€˜ANY OTHER COMMENTSâ€™ and â€˜INTRODUCTIONâ€™ columns - even if just gibberish:


Create a new Framework Matrix.
For rows use the cases in the â€˜Remain Interview Participantsâ€™ dynamic set.
For columns select only the â€˜ANY OTHER COMMENTSâ€™ and â€™INTRODUCTIONâ€™codes.


This makes cells within Framework Matrices â€˜composableâ€™, you can make various larger and smaller matrices based on particular analysis aims without risking losing text or accidentally duplicating work.

title: Find By Case
text:
Look for interview participant cases
Then for our search criteria, we know two things that distinguishes our interview participants cases:

The cases code parts of the interview transcripts.
The cases are classified within the â€˜Peopleâ€™ case classification.


Look for
First, letâ€™s set the dynamic set to look for cases.
Within the â€˜Advancedâ€™ view:



Select the drop-down to choose what to â€˜Look forâ€™.
As we want to find interview participant cases, select â€˜Codes & Casesâ€™




1st Criteria
As our first criteria, letâ€™s add a criteria to return any â€˜codes & casesâ€™ that code any of our interview transcripts.



Within the â€˜Define more criteriaâ€™ section, click the box under â€˜Interactionâ€™.
From the drop-down list select â€˜Codeâ€™.





Click the box under â€˜Optionâ€™.
From the drop-down list select â€˜That Codesâ€™.





Click the box under â€˜Valueâ€™.
From the drop-down list select â€˜Selected Itemsâ€™.


A â€˜Select Project Itemsâ€™ dialogue will pop open.



Expand the â€˜Filesâ€™ folder to see the sub-folders.
Check the tick-box for the â€˜Interviews (2016)â€™ sub-folder. This will select all the interview transcripts in the sub-folder.
Hit â€˜OKâ€™ to confirm the selection.


A wee example of odd minor frustrations NVivo presents. After selecting our interaction, option, value, and files of interest, the â€˜Add to Listâ€™ option remains greyed out â€“ but, why?
â€¦ thereâ€™s a sneaky additional â€˜byâ€™ field that canâ€™t be left blank.



Click the box to the right of â€˜byâ€™ (and under the box for â€˜Select Itemsâ€™)
From the drop-down list, select â€˜Any Userâ€™





Click â€˜Add to Listâ€™.


Our 1st criteria now appears in the giant box for â€˜Find items that match all these criteriaâ€™.



2nd Criteria
Next, we now



Click the box under Interaction.
Select â€˜Codeâ€™ again.





Click the box under Option.
Select â€˜Assigned to Classificationâ€™.





Click the box under Value.
Select â€˜Selected Classificationsâ€™.





Within the Select Project Items dialogue that pops up, tick the checkbox for â€˜Peopleâ€™ case classification.
Hit â€˜OKâ€™ to confirm.





Click â€˜Add to Listâ€™.
Hit â€˜OKâ€™ to save your dynamic list.




Done

And there we have it. Our dynamic set (in red) appears in the Navigation Folder similar to a folder and the items meeting our search criteria (in green) are listed in the Display panel.


Quick?
OK, so maybe that did not feel like a â€˜quickâ€™ example. However, that is more to do with the number of steps required, it being something new, and weird quirks in NVivo. Once you gain a sense for how to create criteria for dynamic sets they can be created in a minute or less. Importantly, remember these are dynamically updated, you only need to create each once.

title: View Results
text:
After hitting â€˜Run Queryâ€™ youâ€™ll be able to see all coded sections that match our Code Query criteria. Just as when viewing regular Codes, there are three tabs on the right-hand side.

Summary - provides a list of the interview transcript files with details for how many â€˜Referencesâ€™ there are - in other words, how many coded sections within this transcript met our criteria - and â€˜Coverageâ€™ - what percentage of the total transcript is captured by the coded sections meeting our criteria.

Reference - is the default view when viewing Code results. It provides a view with all the coded sections, ordered by file they appear in. At the top, in the blue box, you can see it noting that the coded sections that follow are from the Cathy interview transcript, alongside the total references found and coverage. Then it lists each coded section in turn with info for coverage for that individual coded section, in green box.

Text - is similar to the â€˜Referenceâ€™ view, but is like itâ€™s â€˜tab viewâ€™ equivalent. Rather than showing all the coded sections in a single view, it adds a row along the top for all the files, where clicking to select any listed file (in blue box) will change the main view below to show only the coded sections from it.




And, finally, remember when viewing coded sections, you can right-click on any reference (in blue) and select â€˜Open Referenced Fileâ€™ to open the file the coded section is from.

NVivo will open a new tab for the file, jumping to the specific coded section you had right-click on, and with a Coding Query will also highlight other coded sections from it in the file.

title: Project File
text: An NVivo project file for this workshop is available to download from the â€˜NVivo Training 2024/25â€™ group on Social.

title: Project File
text:
The Data Set
The NVivo project file uses data from focus groups and interviews conducted in 2015 and 2016 as part of the Qualitative Election Study of Britain.

The QESB is a collaborative effort between researchers from the UWE Bristol, the University of Dundee, and GESIS in Germany. Since our launch in 2010, our aim has been to learn about the thoughts, feelings, and opinions of every day voters, before and after the UK general election. To this end, we hold focus groups and interviews, online and in-person. During this general election period, we want to hear your thoughts on political life in the UK. Whether itâ€™s about the election, political leaders, parties, economic concerns, the NHS, or climate change, we want to hear it all.

The data is open access and available from the UK Data Service.
For more information on open research and data: - The FAIR principles to improve the findability, accessibility, interoperability, and reuse of digital assets. - UK Data Service hub for archiving qualitative data and secondary analysis. - UK Data Service hub for data skills modules, covering research data management, data for reuse, and more.
Important to making data open access is storing it in â€˜interoperableâ€™, and ideally â€˜open standardâ€™, formats. Interoperable means that the files are not restricted to being opened by a specific single application. An open standard is one that is available for anyone to use, share, or access.
Full â€˜open researchâ€™ remains limited within qualitative research for various reasons. Importantly, whilst there is an open QDPX format for sharing qualitative data analysis projects, it is a â€˜lossyâ€™ format â€“ where folder structures and more are lost when exporting to the open format.
In order then to avoid losing time creating an NVivo project file from scratch / tidying up an imported QDPX file, an NVivo project file has been set up for the workshop and available from Social. This project file is similar to what you would have had at the end of the Intro to NVivo workshop with a few minor tweaks.

title: Project File
text:
Downloading the NVivo Project File
From the group page, to access the file:

Download linkZip file

Scroll down the Feed to find my post with the OneDrive link and click it.

Fail-safe



In case the download link is not working (my university seems to randomly stop share links from working), there is a zip file containing the NVivo project file on Social as well. Use the next tab for instructions to download and extract the zip file.

Select the â€˜Going Further (Feb 2025)â€™ folder.


Click the three dots to open the pop-up menu.
Click â€˜Downloadâ€™ and choose a suitable location to save the file on your device.



From the folder you downloaded it to, right-click on the zip file.
Select â€˜Extract Allâ€¦â€™



Click â€˜Extractâ€™ from the dialogue window and a new folder will be created containing the NVivo project file.

title: Project File
text:
Converting/Upgrading the Project
NVivo project files are â€˜forwardsâ€™ but not â€˜backwardsâ€™ compatible. This means that newer versions of NVivo can open project files created in older versions, but not vice versa.
Due to that, the project file provided was created in NVivo 12, which was the oldest version attendees said they were using in the sign-up survey.
If you are using NVivo 12, you can open the file and directly start working in it.
If you are using a newer version of NVivo or NVivo for MacOS, you will be greeted by a screen asking you to convert/upgrade the file:

Upgrade




(Optional) click â€˜Browseâ€¦â€™ to choose location to save and rename the project file.
Click â€˜Nextâ€™.



From the next screen, hit â€˜Upgradeâ€™ to confirm and start the upgrade. Once complete NVivo will open the file automatically.










NVivo Version Differences



On Windows, there are not any overly significant changes in features from NVivo 12 onwards. The main changes are cosmetic, menu options, and naming conventions.
NVivo for MacOS has always had a different look and menu options. It now has most of the same main features, though a few sub-features remain absent.
Weâ€™ll cover some of these differences as we go. The Resources page also has links to the NVivo User Help Pages for different versions.

title: Going Further
text:
Section Overview



This section covers intermediate-advanced topics in using NVivo for qualitative data analysis.
Key to how the more advanced features will be covered is through considering them as flexible tools for â€˜additive analysisâ€™. They add to the â€˜foundationalâ€™ elements of your project â€“ your files, folders, nodes, cases, and notes â€“ providing ways to retrieve, review, and recontextualise data based on the aims of your analysis. They are part of the extended toolset for crafting various ways to organise, navigate, layer, and weave your analysis and data.
It is assumed, therefore, that you have followed the steps in the first two sections, including importing data, auto-coding by speaker / structure, creating nodes and cases, and doing basic coding.
A project file though is provided on Social with these already setup.

title: Creating new codes
text:
As you progress with coding, some headings may not correspond to our initial question guide.
This is common- these may be questions that were added in later or discussion that came up unexpectedly in the conversation.
An example of this in the Dundee transcript is the question header â€˜Subsequent Political Changeâ€™ :


Method 1 : coding bar


Highlight the text
At the coding bar at the bottom of the screen, check you are coding to â€˜Codesâ€™ (1)
In the section, â€˜Code to:â€™, type â€˜Subsequent political changeâ€™ then press enter (2)
Click the Open Circle to create the code and code highlighted text (3)
You will know this has worked if you see a green pop-up confirming its been coded (4)





You can also check out the new code and what it contains by double-clicking it:





NB. You can use this coding bar to code to existing codes as well. Once you start typing in the bar, NVivo will offer you existing codes to select:





Method 2: right click


While highlighting the text, right click and choose â€˜code selectionâ€™:





In the pop up box, create a new code:





Method 3: drag and drop


While highlighting the text, drag and drop it into the open space below the codes to open a prompt to create a new code:





in the pop up box, name the code and click OK





Top tips
When creating a new code, think of your future self and any collaborators.

When naming codes, use clear, direct, short codes

Always include a description of what you think this code means and what should be included here.

title: NVivo Project Setup
text:
Section Overview



This section will walk you through the steps of creating a new project.
We will cover:

how to import and organise files,
how to create cases and case classifications.
How to connect metadata (e.g.Â demographic information about interviewees)

Follow the steps by clicking through the arrows at the bottom right.


Which NVivo version are we using?
This project setup guide uses screenshots from NVivo Windows 14 and 15. Things may look a little different if youâ€™re working on other versions. Differences with windows R1, 14 and 15 are minimal (where they exist, weâ€™ll try to mention it).
See our cheatsheet for a quick guide to how things differ across versions.
For more complex tasks, we recommend you consult manuals which are relevant to the version you are working in, which can be found in the Resources tab above.

title: How can NVivo help me?
text:
Nvivo is a software package for managing qualitative and mixed methods analysis projects.
You can start an Nvivo project at any point in the research lifecycle: at the design phase, when you have already collected data, or even later.
As an analysis tool, Nvivo can help you:
But aside from helping to structure your analysis, Nvivo can be really helpful as a project management tool, organising your data and other useful information in one place.
You can also use Nvivo to collaborate - you can share projects or using cloud functionality to invite others in.

title: How can NVivo help me?
text:
And what canâ€™t it do?
Important to note, using Nvivo will NOT:

make your analysis better
make meaning- you as the researcher do that
automatically provide objectivity and clarity, or ensure reproducibility

Even though it allows linkage of qualitative and quantitative data, it canâ€™t perform quantitative analysis.
Nvivo takes time to set up; and to make the most of the software, it requires some patience.
It is also more useful for some analysis approaches than others: for example very good for thematic content analysis (which we will cover today), but not so well adapted for others like interpretative phenomenological analysis (IPA).

title: How can NVivo help me?
text:
Navigating online resources
There are a plethora of online resources for Nvivo (of varying qualityâ€¦). This can be overwhelming!
After youâ€™ve done this workshop, you should feel more confident at searching and using these.
Where possible, we will sign post you to more advanced online tutorials.

title: Layering Structure
text:
ğŸ¤” Critical Considerations



Within NVivo guidance and training youâ€™ll often see emphasis being placed on considering your project structure, such as:

Use of folders to organise data, nodes, cases, and memos.
Which case classifications to create.
Auto-coding by speaker, style, and/or structure.

When first starting with NVivo, it may not always be clear why such importance is placed on these considerations.
Letâ€™s say you have the following series of questions during your analysis:

How do I find the cases for all the interview participants?
How do I find the cases for interview participants who supported Remain?
How do I find what views interview participants who supported Remain had on the Leave campaign?
How can I do an initial broad comparison of the views of Remain and Leave campaign supports?
