title: Layering Structure
section: Remain Interview Participants Views on the Leave Campaign
text:
Remain Interview Participants Views on the Leave Campaign
Another benefit to Dynamic Sets is they can be used when creating other objects, such as Queries. This helps us then towards our third question - what were our interview participants who supported Remain say about the Leave Campaign.
Here we can combine our â€œRemain Interview Participantsâ€ Dynamic Set and the â€œLEAVE CAMPAIGNâ€ code.
(If you missed the Intro workshop, this code and others were created by auto-coding the interview transcripts. This was possible as the transcripts have Headings for each of the main topics covered in the interviews.)

Create Coding Query


First, click â€˜Query Criteriaâ€™ in the left Navigation View.



Within the Details list you may see a message explaining what Query criteria are, if so hit â€˜Closeâ€™.



Right-click anywhere within the white space of the Details list, and:

Select â€˜New Queryâ€™
â€˜Codingâ€™




This will open a new tab for creating a Coding Query. Similar to when creating Dynamic Sets in the Advanced view, we have â€˜Search inâ€™ options to limit our query to specific files, items, or folders (in blue). We also have rows for our search criteria (in green).



Coding Query Criteria
We what are our two main criteria?

Interview participants who supported Remain.
Transcript sections where they speak about the Leave Campaign.

To begin then:



Change â€˜All Selected Codes or Casesâ€™ to â€˜Any Selected Code or Caseâ€™. (We want to find any text in the transcripts coded to any of our remain participants case)
Click the â€˜â€¦â€™ to open a â€˜Select Project Itemsâ€™ dialogue to select our cases.



Within the â€˜Select Project Itemsâ€™:


Tick the checkbox for the â€˜Remain Interview Participantsâ€™ dynamic set.
Hit â€˜OKâ€™


And that is it â€“ our first criteria done!
By default a new Coding Query is set to return â€˜Allâ€™ (in light blue) coded sections that meet the listed criteria. So, all we need to do now is add another criteria for our â€˜LEAVE CAMPAIGNâ€™ code.



Click the â€˜+â€™ at the end of our first criteria to add another criteria below.
Change the middle box again to â€˜Any Selected Code or Caseâ€™
Click the â€˜â€¦â€™ once more for a â€˜Select Project Itemsâ€™ dialogue.




2nd Criteria
Within the â€˜Select Project Itemsâ€™ dialogue:



Expand the â€˜Codesâ€™ folder.
Select the â€˜Autocoded (Sections)â€™ subfolder.
Check the tickbox for the â€˜LEAVE CAMPAIGNâ€™ node.
Hit â€˜OKâ€™ to confirm.


Now you can hit Run Query (in pink) to check the query results match what we were expecting and Save Criteriaâ€¦ (in blue) so we can quickly access it again in future. As it is a fairly simple query and fast to run, there is no need to save a separate copy of the results.

title: Layering Structure
text:
View Results

Node Views

After hitting â€˜Run Queryâ€™ youâ€™ll be able to see all coded sections that match our Code Query criteria. Just as when viewing regular Codes, there are three tabs on the right-hand side.

Summary - provides a list of the interview transcript files with details for how many â€˜Referencesâ€™ there are - in other words, how many coded sections within this transcript met our criteria - and â€˜Coverageâ€™ - what percentage of the total transcript is captured by the coded sections meeting our criteria.

Reference - is the default view when viewing Code results. It provides a view with all the coded sections, ordered by file they appear in. At the top, in the blue box, you can see it noting that the coded sections that follow are from the Cathy interview transcript, alongside the total references found and coverage. Then it lists each coded section in turn with info for coverage for that individual coded section, in green box.

Text - is similar to the â€˜Referenceâ€™ view, but is like itâ€™s â€˜tab viewâ€™ equivalent. Rather than showing all the coded sections in a single view, it adds a row along the top for all the files, where clicking to select any listed file (in blue box) will change the main view below to show only the coded sections from it.


Open Referenced File

And, finally, remember when viewing coded sections, you can right-click on any reference (in blue) and select â€˜Open Referenced Fileâ€™ to open the file the coded section is from.

NVivo will open a new tab for the file, jumping to the specific coded section you had right-click on, and with a Coding Query will also highlight other coded sections from it in the file.

title: Layering Structure
text:
Comparing Leave and Remain Supporters
Our final intial question was making an inital broad comparison between the views of Leave and Remain supporters.
We can achieve this with a Matrix Coding Query combining our interview transcript autocoding with are People case classification attribute values.

Matrix Coding Query
Within the Query Criteria, right-click in the white space and -



Select â€˜New Queryâ€™
Then â€˜Matrix Coding Queryâ€™


This will open a new tab for creating a Matrix Coding Query. We can see some of the familar elements again. In yellow we have the optiosn for searching across all Files & Externals or specific Items and Folders. In blue, we have the default â€˜Andâ€™ for handling criteria - other options include Or, Not, and Near. What is different though is rather than adding 1+ criteria, we have a box for selecting Rows and another for Columns, in red.





Adding Rows
It is possible to drag and drop items into the boxes for Rows and Columns, but it is often far quicker and more convenient to use the â€˜Select Project Itemsâ€™ dialogue.



Click the â€˜+â€™ underneath the Rows box on the left.
From the two options click â€˜Select Itemsâ€¦â€™


Then within the Select Project Items dialogue:



Expand the Codes folder.
Check the tickbox for the â€˜Autocoded (Sections)â€™ sub-folder.
Hit â€˜OKâ€™.




Adding Columns
We can follow the same process to select our columns.



Click the â€˜+â€™ underneath the Columns box.
From the two options click â€˜Select Itemsâ€¦â€™


Whilst â€˜Select Attribute Values..â€™ is an option, that is for selecting individual values with criteria (equals, does not equal) one by one. For our purposes, â€˜Select Itemsâ€¦â€™ remains more convenient.



Select the â€˜Case Classificationsâ€™ folder.
Expand the â€˜Peopleâ€™ case classification.
Expand the â€˜2016 voteâ€™ attribute.


After scrolling down a bit:



Check the box for â€˜Leaveâ€™ attribute value.
Check the box for â€˜Remainâ€™ attribute value.
Hit â€˜OKâ€™.




Viewing Results
After selecting our Rows and Columns, we can hit â€˜Run Queryâ€™ (in pink) to create our Coding Matrix. Remember if you want to be able to quickly re-run and update the Coding Matrix to also hit â€˜Save Criteriaâ€¦â€™ (in green) and give it a suitable name.
The Coding Matrix itself (in blue) for each cell in the table shows how many coded sections intersect the two. So, the cell highlight (in yellow) is telling us that 15 sections coded â€˜VOTING DECISIONâ€™ were also coded to cases, where the participant the case is for supported Leave (both in red).





Viewing Cell Coding
That may not seem all that impressive at first. The real power of Coding Matrices though come from double-clicking any of the cells.
That will open a new tab showing all the coded sections being counted in that cell. So, for our example, it opens a tab showing all sections coded â€˜VOTING DECISIONâ€™ AND also coded to a case where the participant supported Leave.
This makes a Coding Matrix the equivalent of a table of shortcuts to more specific queries. Since you can create them with classification attributes, it also makes them ideal for creating queries to aid comparison.

title: Layering Structure
text:
Summary
These examples show different ways you can iteratively build upon your project structure as your analysis progresses.

Your initial structure (folders, codes, cases) can be used to create dynamic sets or query for specific coded sections.
It is possible to add layers upon layers. A dynamic set can be used as part of a query - saving you having to repeat the specific criteria for it again and again.

It can be useful then, in addition to considering your â€˜foundationalâ€™ structure to think about which dynamic sets can add a supporting additional layer to make other tasks easier in the long-term.
It can feel slow and clunky at first getting to grips with creating them, but as you create more your pace will quicken, and through combining them with queries start to more intuitively combine NVivo features in relation to questions that arise during analysis.







Donâ€™t panic!



It is not a problem if you have already started your analysis and not added some of the ways to structure a project file covered in this session.

Most - such as auto-coding and creating folders - can be created at any stage.
Not every project and analysis needs to use all of these structuring options. Some options also add equivalent structure in different ways, where there is some â€˜aesthetic choiceâ€™ in which to use.
If your transcripts do not make use of headers to structure the main topics covered, you can still do manual â€˜broad-brushâ€™ coding. (If having this topic-level coding would benefit your analysis!)

Importantly, for some project structure decisions there is no 100% right/wrong way to do it.
In the example covered we had a â€˜Participantsâ€™ case folder, containing the cases for all participants, and used a dynamic set to get â€˜Interview Participantsâ€™.
Another project structure may have case folders for â€˜Interview participantsâ€™ and â€˜Focus Group participants, and use a dynamic set to get â€™All Participantsâ€™.
Note, this would be feasible as long as the interview and focus group participants are two distinct groups. If some participants took part in both interviews and focus groups, then it would not be possible to have separate Cases folders for them, and the project would need to be structured similar to this example.

title: Question coding: manual approach
text:
Question codes
Another form of basic deductive coding is to code using the interview questions. It might be useful to know how everyone answered the same question across different transcripts.


View the interview questions and their suggested codes by going into the â€˜Research toolsâ€™ folder (1) and opening up â€˜2016 Interview Questionsâ€™ (2):



Here you can see that each section of the interview has a question and suggested short-form code.


The manual approach


Keeping this file open in our Detail View, click on â€˜codesâ€™ in the Navigation View.
Create a new code by right-clicking in the List View section (currently empty)
Click â€˜new codeâ€™





In the pop up box, create codes from the terms in the right-hand column, one at a time. E.g. first make a code called â€˜Introâ€™, then another one called â€˜Referendum campaignâ€™ and so on.
For the â€™description section, it is helpful to copy/paste the full question from the quetsion codes document.
For this example, select â€˜aggregate coding from childrenâ€™ when creating codes. This means that sub-codes under this code will be included when expanding this code and returned in queries using the parent code. This can be changed at any time.




Repeat the steps for all the question codes until your list view looks like this:


Notice that, as we havenâ€™t begun coding, both files and references will show as 0. Once we begin coding, the number under files will tell how many distinct files contain this code. References will tell the number of total times this code has been used (codes may be used several times in the same file).


Code text manually to question headers


Open the first transcript in the folder 2016 interviews, â€˜carterâ€™.
Using Ctrl +F, find the question header â€˜Voting decisionâ€™.





Highlight the text response within this section and drag and drop it into the code listed on the left.





Another way to do this is to highlight to box and use the coding bar at the bottom ofo the screen.





When youâ€™ve done this you will see there is one reference coded to â€˜Voting decisionâ€™; you can click on it to view the text in question.





Some headings in the actual transcripts may not exactly correspond to the question codes, for example, â€˜Referendum Campaign 2â€™ . You could choose to make another coding category for this, but as they represent the same topic, we decided to code them all together into â€˜Referendum campaignâ€™.

title: Create a new project file
text:
To create a new NVivo project file:


Open NVivo and click the â€˜New Projectâ€™ tile on the welcome page. (If you already have an NVivo project open, click â€˜Fileâ€™ on top-left of the ribbon and select â€˜Newâ€™.



Give your project a suitable title.
The file name will be automatically generated.
You can enter a description of the project at this stage as well. While not required, itâ€™s good practice to include something here.
You can choose a language here - English (US) is the default.
Click Next.





Then, choose your preferred save and recovery settings:



NB: The default setting is to have autosave disabled with save prompts every 15 minutes. If you turn on autosave, undo functions are disabled.








ğŸ¤¢ Itâ€™s not you, itâ€™s NVivo



Itâ€™s VERY IMPORTANT to save regularly as NVivo has a notorious habit of crashing. Whilst the autosave reminders can be annoying they are a minor annoyance compared to spending a day working on your analysis without saving for NVivo to unexpectedly crash!

title: Create a new project file
text:
Optional tour

You will be prompted to take a quick tour, which will outline:

Importing data
Cases
Notes
Queries
Visualizations
Centralizing workflow

Skip for now â€“ but may be worth coming back to in the future.

title: Coding material to cases
text:
In this example project, we are most interested in people who have both a 2016 interview and took part in the 2015 pre-election FGDs.
Now that we have established our cases, we will link the responses of the 14 people interviewed in 2016 with their data from the 2015 pre-election focus group.
So, we will link the interview transcript of Walt:

with Waltâ€™s data from the focus group he took part in:

To do this, we need to go into each focus group transcript, search for responses from Walt, and manually code this to Waltâ€™s case.




Open the 2015 Dundee pre-election focus group in your Detail View, and have Cases, People in your List View.
In the focus group data, use Ctrl+F (find) to search for responses from Walt.
Highlight the text and drag it across to Waltâ€™s case in the list view. NB. It may be useful to highlight the preceding moderatorâ€™s question/prompt that Walt is responding to.





You can double click on Waltâ€™s case to check itâ€™s been coded correctly.



Then you would cycle through manually for all instances of Waltâ€™s response in the focus group transcript, then repeat for other participants.

title: Coding material to cases
section: Autocoding using a properly formatted transcript
text:
Autocoding using a properly formatted transcript
Letâ€™s start the process again using the Birmingham FGD.
Notice that in the Birmingham transcript, every time a person speaks it is followed by a colon:



Open the Birmingham 2015 pre-election focus group discussion files and select â€˜autocodeâ€™ from the ribbon.
In the autocode wizard, this time enter speaker names with a colon (e.g.Â Charles:) and click next.
Select Next.





As we already have cases set up for the people we are interested in, select â€˜add to existing classificationsâ€™, â€˜peopleâ€™ and select â€˜finishâ€™.




Check results by clicking into â€˜Peopleâ€™:


If you click on a case e.g.Â â€˜charlesâ€™ you can see there are now 2 files and 38 references linked to that person (1).
In the detail view on the right, you can see all quotes coded to Charlesâ€™ case. (2 and 3)
Finally, you can see a summary of the % of the transcript which is coded to Charles by clicking on the â€˜summaryâ€™ tab on the far right (4).



The moral of the story: autocoding can save you a lot of time in deductive category coding if you understand the algorithm and format data correctly.

title: Uncoding
text:
Uncode when necessary
If youâ€™ve coded something incorrectly, you can uncode text in as many ways as you can code.
After highlighting the text, you can either:


Right-click and choose uncode.





Select â€˜uncodeâ€™ in the document ribbon at the top:





Use the bottom coding bar button / keyboard shortcut (CTRL+SHIFT+F9);

title: Layering Structure
text:
ğŸ¤” Critical Considerations



Within NVivo guidance and training youâ€™ll often see emphasis being placed on considering your project structure, such as:

Use of folders to organise data, nodes, cases, and memos.
Which case classifications to create.
Auto-coding by speaker, style, and/or structure.

When first starting with NVivo, it may not always be clear why such importance is placed on these considerations.
Letâ€™s say you have the following series of questions during your analysis:

How do I find the cases for all the interview participants?
How do I find the cases for interview participants who supported Remain?
How do I find what views interview participants who supported Remain had on the Leave campaign?
How can I do an initial broad comparison of the views of Remain and Leave campaign supports?

text:

title: Developing your initial coding
text:
ğŸ¤” Critical Considerations



At the end of the Start Coding section we covered two key ways in which to develop your coding:

Creating a code hierarchy, so have broader â€˜parentâ€™ codes containing more specific â€˜childâ€™ codes.
Uncoding sections that you had previously coded, whether to undo mistakes or as part of the process of refining what text is coded at each code.

As you continue coding you may start to consider whether more substantial changes are needed.
Firstly, donâ€™t panic - this is a perfectly normal aspect of the coding process. It is rare to end coding with all the codes exactly the same as they were after only coding a couple of transcripts. Instead, codes may be renamed, merged together, recoded to new codes, and so on.
Secondly, whilst it may not be initially obvious, NVivo does provide tools to help manage developing your coding. As examples, we will cover:

Using â€˜organisation codesâ€™ as an additional layer of reflexive coding.
Creating a â€˜code matrix queryâ€™ to view text coded to both thematic and organisation codes.
Linking memos to codes and using memo â€˜see also linksâ€™ as means of jotting down reflections as you code.
Auto-coding memos to find all relevant sections from your memos.
Organising codes with â€˜static setsâ€™ to aid in recoding.

title: Re-Casing
text:
One limitation with Framework Matrices is that Rows must be cases and Columns codes. However, this is another situation where dynamic sets and queries can come to the rescue.
First:


Create a new Coding Query
For criteria, â€˜Coded toâ€™, â€˜Any Selected Code or Caseâ€™, in the â€˜Remain Interview Participantsâ€™ dynamic set.
â€˜Save Criteriaâ€¦â€™ as Sections Coded at Remain Interview Participants.
Click wee triangle next to â€˜Run Queryâ€™ and select â€˜Run and Save Resultsâ€™
In the Store Query Results dialogue on the Location row, click â€˜Selectâ€¦â€™
Select the â€˜Casesâ€™ folder as the location and hit â€˜OKâ€™
Give it a suitable name, such as â€œRemain Supportersâ€
Hit â€˜OKâ€™.


Then:


Create a new dynamic folder â€˜Leave Interview Participantsâ€™ with criteria â€˜Codeâ€™, â€˜That Codesâ€™, any items in the â€˜Interviews (2016)â€™ folder.
Create (and save) a new Coding Query, â€˜Coded toâ€™, â€˜Any Selected Code or Caseâ€™, in the â€˜Leave Interview Participantsâ€™ dynamic set.
â€˜Run and Save Resultsâ€™ to a new case in the â€˜Casesâ€™ folder, â€œLeave Supportersâ€


Finally:


Create a new Framework Matrix
Rows = â€œRemain Supportersâ€ and â€œLeave Supportersâ€
Columns = â€œAutocoded (Sections)â€


Another example:


Create a new Framework Matrix
Rows, first add all individual cases from the â€˜Remain Interview Participantsâ€™ dynamic set.
Rows, second add the â€˜Remain Supportersâ€™ case.
Columns = â€œAutocoded (Sections)â€


This then provides a Framework Matrix with a row for each Remain supporting participant, and a row for summarising across all Remain supporters.

title: Memo See Also Links
text:
What Are â€˜See Also Linksâ€™?
â€˜See Also Linksâ€™ are a means to add a link between text across two different objects, such as text in a memo and text in a transcript. This makes it possible to write reflections on your coding and link directly to any text within the transcript you are directly speaking about.


Creating a See Also Link
To link text within a memo to text in a transcript:


Select the text you want to link to the memo text.
Right-click and select â€˜Copyâ€™.



Then, back in the memo:


Select the memo text you want to be linked.
Right-click and select â€˜Paste as See-Also Linkâ€™.





Viewing See Also Links
See also links appear in red highlighting and, similar to Annotations, a panel listing all See-Also Links within the current tab can be displayed at the bottom of the page.

Importantly, if you right-click red highlighted text or any of the items listed in the See-Also Links panel, you can â€˜Open To Itemâ€™. This will open a new tab for the file that contains the linked text, and will auto-scroll to the exact section the linked text appears.

title: Project File Overview
text:
As a (very) quick overview and reminder of the main workspace areas within NVivo and how we have the project file for this afternoon setup:

Files

Data > Files


Focus Groups (2015): Transcripts from three pre-general election focus groups from 2015.
Interviews (2016): Fourteen telephone interviews on the EU Referendum in 2016.
Literature: Containing two articles by QESB team members, one on using grounded theory, the other on using focus groups.
Project Files: With files that contain additional information about the project, the research phases, and participants who took part.




Codes

Coding > Codes


Codes: Top-level folder with some initial coding created during the Intro to NVivo workshop.

Autocoded (Sections): Sub-folder with the broad-brush themes that were created auto-coding the Headings within the interview transcripts.
Autocoded (Themes): Sub-folder with codes created by auto-coding â€˜themesâ€™.









Warning



We have â€œautocoded themesâ€ within this document merely to provide a broad range of example codes to work with in the exercises. However, in practice, do not rely on such autocoding instead of creating and coding with your own codes.




Cases

Cases > Cases


Interviewer: Cases created when â€˜autocoding by speakerâ€™ that code transcript sections where an interviewer / moderator from the research team is speaking.
Participants: Cases created when â€˜autocoding by speakerâ€™ that code transcript sections where participants are speaking.
Case Classifications: Top-level folder contains the case classifications and their attributes. For this project, there is only one case classification - â€˜Peopleâ€™.

People: Sub-folder with all cases classified as â€˜Peopleâ€™, where can see the attributes for specific participants. (Note - the interviewer cases are also classified as people, in many cases you would want to remove from the same classification as participants.)





Notes



Memos: NVivoâ€™s built-in note-taking system. Contains a few existing memos with further project info and reflectives on initial analysis.
Framework Matrices: Create summaries for cases by node. Currently, empty.
Annotations: Annotations added to files, with couple examples.
See-Also Links: Use to link content/files to other content/files. Currently, empty.




Sets



Static Sets: Manually created collections of project items, of any type. Think of this as a way to group and organise items for specific tasks without changing their primary structure. For example, a code can only exist within a single folder within the â€œCoding > Codesâ€ section. However, it can be included within an unlimited number of static sets.
Dynamic Sets: Collections of project items created based on search criteria. As they are criteria based they also auto-update based on any changes in your project. For example, if you had a dynamic set for all codes used to code focus group transcripts, each time you use a new code when coding the focus groups, it will automatically then be included in the dynamic set.








NVivo 12 - â€˜search foldersâ€™



Dynamic Sets are a new name given to what were called â€˜search foldersâ€™ in NVivo 12. They operate exactly the same, all that is different is the name.




Queries



Query Criteria: Location to store saved queries, saving you from having to manually put them together each time.
Query Results: Location to store query results. This can be useful for more complex queries that take a long-time to process to save having to re-run it every time â€“ just remember it wonâ€™t reflect any changes to your project file. Query results can also be used to create new nodes and cases.
Coding Matrices: Similar to the above but for the results of a coding matrix. By default manually created coding matrices saved results with be in Query Results, but they can manually moved across. Coding matrices automatically produced, such as when autocoding by theme, are stored here by default.

title: Combine Sets and Queries
text:
Another benefit to Dynamic Sets is they can be used when creating other objects, such as Queries. This helps us then towards our third question - what were our interview participants who supported Remain say about the Leave Campaign.
Here we can combine our â€œRemain Interview Participantsâ€ Dynamic Set and the â€œLEAVE CAMPAIGNâ€ code.
(If you missed the Intro workshop, this code and others were created by auto-coding the interview transcripts. This was possible as the transcripts have Headings for each of the main topics covered in the interviews.)




First, click â€˜Query Criteriaâ€™ in the left Navigation View.



Within the Details list you may see a message explaining what Query criteria are, if so hit â€˜Closeâ€™.



Right-click anywhere within the white space of the Details list, and:

Select â€˜New Queryâ€™
â€˜Codingâ€™




This will open a new tab for creating a Coding Query. Similar to when creating Dynamic Sets in the Advanced view, we have â€˜Search inâ€™ options to limit our query to specific files, items, or folders (in blue). We also have rows for our search criteria (in green).




We what are our two main criteria?

Interview participants who supported Remain.
Transcript sections where they speak about the Leave Campaign.

To begin then:



Change â€˜All Selected Codes or Casesâ€™ to â€˜Any Selected Code or Caseâ€™. (We want to find any text in the transcripts coded to any of our remain participants case)
Click the â€˜â€¦â€™ to open a â€˜Select Project Itemsâ€™ dialogue to select our cases.



Within the â€˜Select Project Itemsâ€™:


Tick the checkbox for the â€˜Remain Interview Participantsâ€™ dynamic set.
Hit â€˜OKâ€™


And that is it â€“ our first criteria done!
By default a new Coding Query is set to return â€˜Allâ€™ (in light blue) coded sections that meet the listed criteria. So, all we need to do now is add another criteria for our â€˜LEAVE CAMPAIGNâ€™ code.



Click the â€˜+â€™ at the end of our first criteria to add another criteria below.
Change the middle box again to â€˜Any Selected Code or Caseâ€™
Click the â€˜â€¦â€™ once more for a â€˜Select Project Itemsâ€™ dialogue.





Within the â€˜Select Project Itemsâ€™ dialogue:



Expand the â€˜Codesâ€™ folder.
Select the â€˜Autocoded (Sections)â€™ subfolder.
Check the tickbox for the â€˜LEAVE CAMPAIGNâ€™ node.
Hit â€˜OKâ€™ to confirm.


Now you can hit Run Query (in pink) to check the query results match what we were expecting and Save Criteriaâ€¦ (in blue) so we can quickly access it again in future. As it is a fairly simple query and fast to run, there is no need to save a separate copy of the results.

title: Combine Sets and Queries
text:
Another benefit to Dynamic Sets is they can be used when creating other objects, such as Queries. This helps us then towards our third question - what were our interview participants who supported Remain say about the Leave Campaign.
Here we can combine our â€œRemain Interview Participantsâ€ Dynamic Set and the â€œLEAVE CAMPAIGNâ€ code.
(If you missed the Intro workshop, this code and others were created by auto-coding the interview transcripts. This was possible as the transcripts have Headings for each of the main topics covered in the interviews.)




First, click â€˜Query Criteriaâ€™ in the left Navigation View.



Within the Details list you may see a message explaining what Query criteria are, if so hit â€˜Closeâ€™.

Select â€˜New Queryâ€™
â€˜Codingâ€™




This will open a new tab for creating a Coding Query. Similar to when creating Dynamic Sets in the Advanced view, we have â€˜Search inâ€™ options to limit our query to specific files, items, or folders (in blue). We also have rows for our search criteria (in green).




We what are our two main criteria?

Interview participants who supported Remain.
Transcript sections where they speak about the Leave Campaign.

To begin then:



Change â€˜All Selected Codes or Casesâ€™ to â€˜Any Selected Code or Caseâ€™. (We want to find any text in the transcripts coded to any of our remain participants case)
Click the â€˜â€¦â€™ to open a â€˜Select Project Itemsâ€™ dialogue to select our cases.



Within the â€˜Select Project Itemsâ€™:


Tick the checkbox for the â€˜Remain Interview Participantsâ€™ dynamic set.
Hit â€˜OKâ€™


And that is it â€“ our first criteria done!
By default a new Coding Query is set to return â€˜Allâ€™ (in light blue) coded sections that meet the listed criteria. So, all we need to do now is add another criteria for our â€˜LEAVE CAMPAIGNâ€™ code.



Click the â€˜+â€™ at the end of our first criteria to add another criteria below.
Change the middle box again to â€˜Any Selected Code or Caseâ€™
Click the â€˜â€¦â€™ once more for a â€˜Select Project Itemsâ€™ dialogue.





Within the â€˜Select Project Itemsâ€™ dialogue:



Expand the â€˜Codesâ€™ folder.
Select the â€˜Autocoded (Sections)â€™ subfolder.
Check the tickbox for the â€˜LEAVE CAMPAIGNâ€™ node.
Hit â€˜OKâ€™ to confirm.


Now you can hit Run Query (in pink) to check the query results match what we were expecting and Save Criteriaâ€¦ (in blue) so we can quickly access it again in future. As it is a fairly simple query and fast to run, there is no need to save a separate copy of the results.

title: Find by Attribute
text:
So, our next question was finding all our interview participants who support Remain the EU Referendum. As it is similar steps to follow, a shortened version of the instructions are included below.




Create a new dynamic set (right-click on â€˜Dynamic Setsâ€™ and select â€˜New Dynamic Setâ€¦â€™) and provide it relevant Name and Description.

Then in â€˜Search Criteriaâ€™ tab and â€˜Advancedâ€™ sub-tab:



Look for: â€˜Codes % Casesâ€™
Interaction: â€œCodeâ€
Option: â€œThat Codesâ€
Value: â€œSelect Itemsâ€ & tick the checkbox next to â€˜Interviews (2016)â€™ in the pop up dialogue.
By: â€œAny Userâ€
Hit â€œAdd to Listâ€







This time for the 2nd criteria, select â€˜Attributeâ€™ for the interaction.

Within the Select Project Item dialogue that opens:



Expand the People case classification.
Select â€˜2016 voteâ€™ (the attribute to Remain/Leave in the EU Referendum)
Hit â€˜OKâ€™


All thatâ€™s left to do:



Change the â€˜Valueâ€™ we are selecting for to â€˜Remainâ€™.
Click â€˜Add to Listâ€™.
Hit â€˜OKâ€™ to create the Dynamic Set.


And again our Dynamic Set is shown in red and the results in green.

As you can see, once you start getting a sense for how to create search criteria, it becomes relatively quick for creating them â€“ most of the time spent is figuring out how to do it in the first place.

title: Find by Attribute
text:
So, our next question was finding all our interview participants who support Remain the EU Referendum. As it is similar steps to follow, a shortened version of the instructions are included below.




Create a new dynamic set (right-click on â€˜Dynamic Setsâ€™ and select â€˜New Dynamic Setâ€¦â€™) and provide it relevant Name and Description.

Then in â€˜Search Criteriaâ€™ tab and â€˜Advancedâ€™ sub-tab:



Look for: â€˜Codes % Casesâ€™
Interaction: â€œCodeâ€
Option: â€œThat Codesâ€
Value: â€œSelect Itemsâ€ & tick the checkbox next to â€˜Interviews (2016)â€™ in the pop up dialogue.
By: â€œAny Userâ€
Hit â€œAdd to Listâ€







This time for the 2nd criteria, select â€˜Attributeâ€™ for the interaction.

Within the Select Project Item dialogue that opens:



Expand the People case classification.
Select â€˜2016 voteâ€™ (the attribute to Remain/Leave in the EU Referendum)
Hit â€˜OKâ€™


All thatâ€™s left to do:



Change the â€˜Valueâ€™ we are selecting for to â€˜Remainâ€™.
Click â€˜Add to Listâ€™.
Hit â€˜OKâ€™ to create the Dynamic Set.


And again our Dynamic Set is shown in red and the results in green.

As you can see, once you start getting a sense for how to create search criteria, it becomes relatively quick for creating them â€“ most of the time spent is figuring out how to do it in the first place.

title: Synthesis, Intrepretation, and Themes
text:
ğŸ¤” Critical Considerations



Within qualitative analysis youâ€™ll often hear terms like â€˜synthesisâ€™, â€˜interpretationâ€™, and â€˜themesâ€™. At times this can vague and unhelpful, such as the over-used phrase claiming â€˜themes emergeâ€™ through analysis, without specifying precisely how.
We have though already covered some of the ways through which your analysis develops beyond the simple coding of text:

Organising your coding within a code hierarchy, identifying broader parent codes and more specific child codes.
Memos for exploring initial reflections and interpretation.
Static sets and queries for exploring and refining your coding as your analysis develops.

Another useful feature for building synthesis, interpetation, and themes is framework matrices. Originally, in pen and paper days, framework matrices were often seen as an alternative to thematic coding, where instead of going through transcripts coding text, a matrix is created with rows for each participant and columns for the themes / codes. Information is then summarised for each participant for the columns, aiding in identifcation of patterns.
Within NVivo this is no longer an â€˜either/orâ€™ and â€˜bothâ€™ is a valid option. Importantly, NVivo makes it possible to create a workflow for moving from coding to framework matrices.

title: Using Static Sets
text:
What are Static Sets?
Static Sets provide a means for collating and organising objects - whether transcripts, cases, codes, queries, etc - from across your project file. In contrast to the main workspace views within NVivo (Files, Coding, â€¦), where for example a code can only exist in a single specific folder within the Coding section, a code can be added to an unlimited number of static sets. This makes them ideal for making collections of codes for specific purposes outwith your main coding hierarchy.
For example, say you wanted to recode text coded at three existing codes to three new codes you have created.


Letâ€™s Create a Static Set
First, create a new static set:


Navigate to Sets > Static Sets
Right-click in any available white space.
Left-click to select â€˜New Static Setâ€¦â€™



Then within the â€˜New Static Setâ€™ dialogue:


Provide a suitable â€˜Nameâ€™, for this exercise go with â€˜Old Codesâ€™
Hit â€˜OKâ€™ to confirm



Next, letâ€™s add some of our existing coding to the set. Navigate to â€˜Autocoded (Themes)â€™ and:


Select three existing codes (preferable ones with higher number of coded sections)
Drag and drop them onto the â€˜Old Codesâ€™ Static Set we created.


Now, letâ€™s create another set and our new nodes:


Repeat the instructions for creating a new static set and name it â€˜New Codesâ€™.
Within your Coding > Codes top-level folder create three new codes of your choice, for simplicity Iâ€™m just going with â€˜Aâ€™, â€˜Bâ€™, â€˜Câ€™.
Add these three codes to the â€˜New Codesâ€™ static set.




Coded to Old Codes, but not New Codes
Our familiar friend â€˜Matrix Coding Queryâ€™ can now be combined with these sets to help us with the recoding process. We can create a matrix coding query that has row for our â€˜Old Codesâ€™ static set and column for our â€˜New Codesâ€™ static set, showing a cell with all text that is not yet coded to our new codes.
So, letâ€™s create a new matrix coding query:


Navigate to Queries > Query Criteria
Right-click on â€˜Query Criteriaâ€™ or any available white space and select â€˜New Queryâ€™.
Click on â€˜Matrix Coding Queryâ€™



Then within the Matrix Coding Query:


Hit the â€˜+â€™ button.
Click â€˜Select Itemsâ€¦â€™



Then, within the â€˜Select Project Itemsâ€™ dialogue:


Select â€˜Static Setsâ€™
Tick the box for â€˜Old Codesâ€™
Hit â€˜OKâ€™.



Repeat steps for the Columns and our New Codes set:


Hit the â€˜+â€™ button.
Click â€˜Select Itemsâ€¦â€™



Then:


Select â€˜Static Setsâ€™.
Tick the box for â€˜New Codesâ€™.
Hit the â€˜OKâ€™ button.



We want this matrix to aid us in recoding text from our â€˜oldâ€™ to â€˜newâ€™ codes, so in comparison to the last time we created one where wanted to find text coded at both the row and column, this time we want to find text coded at our â€˜oldâ€™ codes, but not our â€˜newâ€™ codes. So:


For the â€˜Coding at rows â€¦ columnsâ€™ drop-down, change it to â€˜Notâ€™



Remember to also:


Click â€˜Save Criteriaâ€¦â€™
Give the query a name such as â€˜From Old to Newâ€™.




The Query Results
Whilst this will create a single cell, double-clicking will open a coding results tab with all sections coded at the codes in the â€˜Old Codesâ€™ static set.
You can now work your way recoding to the New Codes. Importantly, during recoding you can hit â€˜Run Queryâ€™ and get an update of how many sections are left to recode. This can be extremely useful if whilst recoding you realise you actually need a fourth new code â€˜Dâ€™. You can create it, add it to â€˜New Codesâ€™ static set and â€˜Run Queryâ€™ for your â€˜Recoding Old with Newâ€™ Matrix Code Query.
Remember you can change the â€˜coding contentâ€™ to view more text surrounding the sections coded to your old codes. That wonâ€™t make a difference for most of the codes in this project file, but if you only coded sentences or even short phrases, this will add back some additional context.

Similarly, you can turn on coding stripes and highlighting using the static set as a filter.




Other uses for static sets
Static Sets can save a lot of headaches and frustration when adopting a coding approach that has multiple stages in developing and refining your codes or working on a large project with multiple researchers coding across different policy areas where you have a lot of codes across multiple folders that you may want retrieve quickly.
Similarly, they can also be used for:

Grouping conceptual related codes outside your main coding schema.
Collating a mix of items (files, cases, codes) that are pertinent to an aspect of your analysis.
Making a group of participants with similar experiences, but where it would not necessarily make sense to capture it using Attributes.

title: Autocode Memos
text:
As another example of how flexible some of NVivos features are, as with files, it is possible to autocode memos - in exactly same way as autocoded the transcripts.


Right-click the memo you created.
Select â€˜Autocodeâ€¦â€™



Within the Autocode Wizard dialogue:


Select â€˜Use the style or structureâ€™
Click â€˜Hitâ€™



For Step 2:
:: instructions
Select â€˜Paragraphâ€™ styles and hit â€˜Nextâ€™

:::
For Step 3:


Select â€˜Heading 1â€™
Click the â€˜>>â€™ button to add it to â€˜Selected paragraph stylesâ€™
Hit â€˜Nextâ€™



Finally, for Step 4:


Change â€˜Underâ€™ to â€˜New Folderâ€™
Provide it an appropriate Name, such as â€˜Autocoding (Memo Sections)â€™
Hit â€˜Finishâ€™



Then, to view the autocoding:


Navigate to â€˜Autocoding (Memo Sections)â€™ (or whatever name you provided)



This may not seem like much with just a single or couple memos, but if you had a series of structure memos this would let you quickly find and navigate them by specific sections. Going through the â€˜Unsureâ€™ sections, for example, may help you identify new code to create or ones to replace.
Say you decided to create three new codes to outright replace three old ones, but this is made tricky as the each code does replace one code, but instead cuts across content in 2-3 of the old codes.
This is where static sets come in handyâ€¦

title: Coding Matrix Query
text:
What is a Coding Matrix Query?
A Coding Matrix Query finds all text that is meets conditions between two codes - such as text coded at Code A and Code B or text coded at Code X but not Code Y. You provide a list of codes to use for the rows, and another for the columns, alongside speciftying whether to use and/or/not condition between the two.


Creating a Coding Matrix Query
First, ensure to have done some initial coding to the organisation codes:


Select two or three existing codes from the top-level Codes folder or â€˜Autocoded (Theme)â€™ sub-folder.
Open tabs for to view the code results for each.
Quickly go through coding sections from the code results to â€˜Exampleâ€™, â€˜Goldâ€™, and â€˜Unsureâ€™.


Then, to create a coding matrix:


Go to the Query Criteria folder
Right-click and select New Query
and, Matrix Coding Query









ğŸ¤¢ Itâ€™s not you, itâ€™s NVivo



Despite there being a Queries > Coding Matrices section, we do not use that for creating a new Matrix Coding Query. That section is where you can find the saved results from a Matrix Query. And the eagle eyed may have the following questions:

There is a â€˜Query Resultsâ€™ section, so why also have a seperate â€˜Coding Matricesâ€™ section?
You create a â€˜Matrix Coding Queryâ€™, but its results are referred to as a â€˜Coding Matrixâ€™?

The answer to both is â€˜Yes, but no idea why - thatâ€™s just NVivo being NVivoâ€™.


Then within the Matrix Coding Query:


Hit the â€˜+â€™ button.
Click â€˜Select Itemsâ€¦â€™



Within the â€˜Select Project Itemsâ€™ dialogue, select the three codes you picked:


Navigate to the folder containing them.
Check the boxes for them.
Hit the â€˜OKâ€™ button.



Repeat steps for the Columns with our organisation codes:


Hit the â€˜+â€™ button.
Click â€˜Select Itemsâ€¦â€™



Then:


Select Codes.
Expand the parent z - org code. (or name you chose for it)
Tick the boxes for the three organisation codes.
Hit the â€˜OKâ€™ button.



Finally:


Hit â€˜Run Queryâ€™



Remember to also -


Hit â€˜Save Criteriaâ€¦â€™
Provide a suitable name.









ğŸ¤¢ Itâ€™s not you, itâ€™s NVivo



With some queries NVivo will ask you for a name upfront before letting you add criteria, with others you can modify criteria before saving - just always ensure if its a query you plan to reuse again in future to â€˜Save Criteriaâ€¦â€™ before closing the tab for it.


This will then produce a coding matrix you can then use to find sections coded at both a regular and organisation code.
It may not look that useful at first, is it not just a bunch of cells with numbers?
Each number is a count of how many sections of text are coded for the relevant row and column codes for the cell.
Far more important though is double-clicking on any of the cells! That will open a Code Results view for all the text for that cell. So, if you click on the cell where row = campaign and column = Gold, it will open a results view showing all text coded at both campaign and Gold - in other words, all the text for campaign that we coded as potential gold for using as quotes when writing up.

title: Creating a Framework Matrix
text:
To create a framework matrix, we first need to navigate to the location where they are stored:

Notes > Framework Matrices


Then, to create a new framework matrix:


Right-click in white space.
Select â€˜New Framework Matrixâ€¦â€™



This will bring up the â€˜New Framework Matrixâ€™ dialogue:


Provide it with a suitable name.



After that:


Select the Rows tab.
Use the left-hand â€˜Selectâ€™ button to open a dialogue and select the Participant case folder.
Use the right-hand â€˜Selectâ€™ button to open a dialogue and select 1-4 attributes from the People classification that will be used to sort how the rows for participant cases will be ordered.
(Optional) if you pick more than one attribute, you can use the up/down arrows on the right, in blue, to change their order.



Finally:


Select the Colums tab.
Use the â€˜Selectâ€™ button to pick codes to use as columns, in this case select the â€˜Auto-Code (Sections)â€™ folder.
(Optional) use the arrows on the right to change the order of the codes.



Hit â€˜OKâ€™ and after a few seconds the Framework Matrix will have been created and will automatically open.

title: Design your own Nvivo project: first steps
text:
Before you start building your own Nvivo project,itâ€™s a good idea to think through the components and likely structure in advance:
ğŸ¤” Ask yourself about the following:


What types of data and files do I have?
These need to be digitized, but could include text items likeâ€¦
- transcripts of interviews/focus groups 
- quantitative metadata
- field notes 
- research tools
- policy documents
- literature 
- archive materials
It is also possible to include things like..
- photographs or images
- video/audio 
- maps 
CAUTION: adding large files to Nvivo slows the software down dramatically.
For that reason we advise against using Nvivo for compiling many PDF articles, for example. Referencing software might be better for managing academic literature. The same goes for video/audio files.
It is helpful to imagine how these things are best organised in a file hierarchy.


What are the main units of analysis?
These could be individuals youâ€™ve interviewed, organisations youâ€™ve studied, communities youâ€™ve worked in, etc. And you could have nested units at different levels (e.g.Â individuals nested in communities).
These units of analysis might later get created as â€˜casesâ€™ in the Nvivo project file, which enable you to keep information about that case all in one place.
For example, a case within a project file might represent an individual, with multiple linked interview transcripts, some fieldnotes, and some metadata telling of their demographics.
These cases and case structures can evolve as you conduct your research, too.


What are the characteristics of these units?
Now consider what characteristics of these units you have measured. For example, for individuals you have interviewed, you might have socioedemographic data recorded (e.g.Â age, sex, education) This would be known as metadata, and might be recorded in a spreadsheet or table.


What are the linkages within the project?
This might be files that are linked within a single case or individual, for example an individual who has 2 sequential interview transcripts. Or, it might be linkages between different individuals or cases who live in the same household.


What are likely to be key topics or themes?
This may be unknown at this stage, but you might imagine some key/core themes based on your research question such as â€˜trust in institutionsâ€™, â€˜sense of lossâ€™, etc.
These themes might become â€˜codesâ€™ within your Nvivo project.

title: Nvivo versions
text:
In recent years, there have been several different releases of QSR Nvivo software, in both Windows and Mac versions. Different institutions may subscribe to different versions.
This matters because some features differ and compatibility cannot always be assumed, which can be quite annoying. Where possible, we recommend working with a windows version, because you have more advanced features available. Some windows features are â€˜hiddenâ€™ for the mac versions.
The most commonly encountered versions :
 Between Nvivo versions, there is forwards compatibility only. This means that you can open an Nvivo nvp file made in Nvivo 12 in Nvivo Release 1, but not the other way around. To open an older file in a more recent version, open the file, and then click â€˜upgradeâ€™.

â€˜Living Documentsâ€™



These pages are â€˜living documentsâ€™, they will continually and iteratively be updated over time.
I cannot promise additional content will be added within any specific period of time, but I will be taking note of frequently asked questions, different use cases, and any issues encountered. These will be used to update and add to the existing content.
Similarly, following any of the sessions â€“ or if you were unable to attend the in-person workshops and are following along online - please feel free to email any questions: alasdair.stewart@glasgow.ac.uk or katherine.keenan@st-andrews.ac.uk.
Note - we take absolutely no offense if your question is due to any of the materials being unclear! In all our time teaching, the most useful feedback we have received has been from students pointing out something that was unclear to them or raised further questions.

title: Importing files
text:
Import 2016 interview files

From the Import Ribbon, select â€˜Filesâ€™.
Navigate to your saved folders and open â€œ2016 Interviewsâ€.
Select the 14 transcript files (saved by first name), and click â€˜openâ€™:




Automatically create cases as you import
Next, a box will pop up:



Tick the box in the import window to â€˜Create a case for each imported fileâ€™ (1).
As this is a new project, select â€œcreate new classificationâ€ and label it â€˜peopleâ€™ then click â€˜importâ€™ (2).
Click import (3)








ğŸ¤¢ Itâ€™s not you, itâ€™s NVivo



If your Nvivo hangs or says â€˜not respondingâ€™ when you import files, donâ€™t panic. This is normal Nvivo behaviour and usually resolves. It is a fussy program and if you have an older machine it can sometimes take a while to perform some actions. It does crash from time to time, which is why its important to save your work as you go.









What is a â€˜caseâ€™ in Nvivo?



A case represents a unit of analysis, and this is most commonly people youâ€™ve interviewed, organisations you worked with, communities, families, etc. In this example, cases are people that have been interviewed. But it could be any kind of unit: people, places, organizations, events or other entities that you want to analyze and compare. Cases allow you to link information together related to that person, place or organisation. It makes it easy for you to see everything related to a single unit in one place. See the page on cases and case classifications for more info. Not all projects require cases, but if you make comparisons across people or any other units, itâ€™s a good idea as opens up many other functionalities.




After Import
You will see your uploaded files appear in â€˜Filesâ€™:



You can see that cases have been created for these 14 people by scrolling down the left-hand menu to â€˜casesâ€™:



For each person, they now have a â€˜caseâ€™ icon (1) and 1 file associated (the transcript) (2); they have been created under the classification â€˜Peopleâ€™.



Weâ€™ll come back to cases in a moment.


Organise interview transcripts into a folder

Create a new folder under files by right clicking on files, select â€˜new folderâ€™,name it â€˜2016 Interviewsâ€™, add a brief description of you like, click OK to finish.




Move files to the 2016 Interviews folder, by selecting all (ctrl+A) and dragging and dropping to the new folder.




Create a folder structure

Right click on â€˜Filesâ€™ in the Navigation View and create new folders for:

2015 pre-election FGDs
Literature
Research tools





Import 2015 focus group data

Right click on the â€˜2015 pre-election FGDsâ€™ folder in the Navigation view and select â€˜Import Filesâ€™
In the pop-up window, navigate to your saved folder for 2015 FGDs Import the three transcripts.








Important



As you have already created cases when you imported the transcripts, DO NOT create cases again.

Instead, ensure that the box for â€˜Create a case for each imported fileâ€™ is unticked.





Import research tools but not metadata
We can also import files to by directly dragging and dropping them from your file explorer into NVivo.

To populate our â€˜research toolsâ€™ folder, open the â€˜other documentsâ€™ folder on your computer. Select all of the MS word documents (i.e.Â do not select â€˜metadataâ€™ excel file) and drag-and-drop them into list view space.




Import literature
Import â€˜Litâ€™ files to â€˜Litâ€™ folder.
Using the method of your choice, import the 3 files from the â€˜Litâ€™ folder from your downloads into the â€˜Litâ€™ folder in NVivo
Remember, DO NOT create new cases.

title: Question coding: autocoding approach
text:
Autocoding approach
Question coding manually is incredibly repetitive and therefore well suited to automation.
Once again, you must ensure transcripts are appropriately formatted to take advantage of autocoding features.


First, ensure that all of the question headers (e.g.Â â€˜Leave Campaignâ€ â€™Voting Decisionâ€™ etc ) are formatted in MS Word using the same style (e.g.Â heading 1â€™). Check this by opening up a transcript, go to â€˜editâ€™, find a question heading and checking how itâ€™s formatted. Here you can see the headings are formatted as â€˜heading 1â€™:



You are best to do this before uploading the documents to NVivo, although it is possible to do this formatting within NVivo.
We are going to autocode all interview transcripts at once.


go into the folder â€˜2016 Interviewsâ€™ select all (Ctrl+A) (1)
then click autocode (2)
On the autocode wizard box, select â€˜paragraph stylesâ€™ (3)
Click next (4)





On step 2 of the autocode wizard, you will see the possible paragraph styles. Select â€˜heading 1â€™ and click â€˜nextâ€™





On step 3 of the wizard, you are asked to choose where to store the codes.
Here we choose to create a new folder (2)and call this â€˜Interviews by questionâ€™(2)
Click finish (3).





See the results of the autocoding by clicking into the folder â€˜Interviews by questionâ€™ that you have just created.
You can view the text that is coded to any code e.g.Â â€˜Leave Campaignâ€™ by double clicking it. On the right hand side you can see excerpts from across different transcripts coded to this code.





Tidying up autocoding: merging codes
Some codes are very similar e.g.Â â€˜THE DAY OF THE REFERENDUMâ€™ and â€˜THE DAY OF THE REFERENDUM 2â€™ - letâ€™s merge these.


First, highlight one of them e.g.Â â€˜THE DAY OF THE REFERENDUM 2â€™ and right click ->copy.





Then click on the other one i.e.Â â€˜THE DAY OF THE REFERENDUMâ€™, right click, then choose â€˜Merge into selected codeâ€™ .





On the pop up box, you have the chance to change the settings about what you merge, we just stick with the default:



You will notice that the number of codes for â€˜THE DAY OF THE REFERENDUMâ€™ had increased.
You can delete the one you just copied â€˜â€™THE DAY OF THE REFERENDUM 2â€™.


Extra video tutorials about autocoding
After the class, you may find these additional video tutorials useful:

title: Primers on qualitative data and analysis
text: If you have never had formal masters-level training in qualitative enquiry, we recommend you follow some introductory material before you atten the NVivo workshops. This will help you get the most out of the day.

title: Primers on qualitative data and analysis
section: What is qualitative enquiry and data?
text:
What is qualitative enquiry and data?
Engage with one or all of the following:

The Discipline and Practice of Qualitative Research which is Chapter 1 in Denzin and Lincoln, eds.Â (2018) The SAGE Handbook of Qualitative Research. 5th ed.Â London: SAGE Publications.
Introduction to qualitative research methods - Part 1 by Bhangu, Provost, and Caduff (2023) in Perspectives in Clinical Research 14(1) pp.39-42
Qualitative research the basics YouTube video by Degree Doctor (Dr Elizabeth Yardley)

title: Primers on qualitative data and analysis
text:
What is coding?

An Introduction to Codes and Coding which is Chapter 1 in SaldaÃ±a (2013) The Coding Manual for Qualitative Researchers. 2nd ed.Â London: Sage Publications Ltd.

title: Primers on qualitative data and analysis
text:
What is thematic analysis?
Thematic analysis is a commonly used method within qualitative analysis, suitable for using with software like NVivo.
Papers:

Braun, Virginia, and Victoria Clarke (2006) â€˜Using Thematic Analysis in Psychologyâ€™. Qualitative Research in Psychology 3(2):77â€“101. doi: 10.1191/1478088706qp063oa.
Braun, Virginia, and Victoria Clarke (2019) â€˜Reflecting on Reflexive Thematic Analysisâ€™. Qualitative Research in Sport, Exercise and Health 11(4):589â€“97. doi: 10.1080/2159676X.2019.1628806.
Byrne, David. (2022) â€˜A Worked Example of Braun and Clarkeâ€™s Approach to Reflexive Thematic Analysisâ€™. Quality & Quantity 56(3):1391â€“1412. doi: 10.1007/s11135-021-01182-y.
Kiger, Michelle E., and Lara Varpio. (2020) â€˜Thematic Analysis of Qualitative Data: AMEE Guide No.Â 131â€™. Medical Teacher 42(8):846â€“54. doi: 10.1080/0142159X.2020.1755030.

YouTube:

Thematic analysis in qualitative research by Degree Doctor (Dr Elizabeth Yardley)


Reflexive Thematic analysis (Braun and Clarke) : lectures and videos

A foundational textbook on this approach with interactive online content.

Accompanying youtube lectures:

title: Cases
text:
Recap: what is an Nvivo case?

In Nvivo, a case represents a unit of analysis.

This could be:

people youâ€™ve interviewed,
events,
organisations you worked with,
communities,
families, etc.

Basically anything you want to organise and compare.
Before you build a new project, you should decide what are your cases/units of analysis.
In this QESB project, we have created cases for every person with a 1-2-1 interview; heer you can see Claireâ€™s case highlighted:

and you can see that each person has 1 file associated with them (the interview transcript).


and why do I need cases?
Cases allow you to link information together related to unit. They help you to connect and draw material across your files. They are also very useful if you want to add metadata (e.g.Â sociodemographic info)
Some examples:

Connect text from focus groups to cases of individuals;
Connect photos, maps, audio, to cases of events;

Connect parliamentary debates to cases of policy /laws.

Hereâ€™s an example taken from an Nvivo explainer on cases:

You donâ€™t have to use cases, but doing us unlocks a lot of extra functionality, and it makes a lot of sense if you have anything more than just a few transcripts.

title: Qualitative Election Study of Britain
text:
We will use data from a longitudinal qualitative study called the Qualitative Election Study of Britain.
Hereâ€™s an explanation of the study by itâ€™s leads:
Hear a little bit about the study from one of its PIs, Ediza Carvalho, based at the University of Dundee:
The data is open access and available from the UK Data Service.
We chose this dataset because it contains a variety of file formats, including focus group discussions and in-depth interviews conducted around elections and referenda which are related over time in 2010, 2014, 2015, 2016, and 2017.

title: Qualitative Election Study of Britain
section: The data subset we are using
text:
The data subset we are using
The data we will be working with was collected in 2015 and 2016, and were timed to collect opinions prior to the UK 2015 General Election, and just after the EU or â€˜Brexitâ€™ Referendum. This period was one of great political unpredictability and voter volatility. Both of those votes had controversial and unexpected results: the 2015 Election was a surprise win for the Conservatives, and in Scotland, the Scottish National Party made huge gains over Labour. The 2016 EU referendum resulted in a 52% vote to leave the European Union, and this marked a change in the UKâ€™s relationship with Europe and the rest of the world.

The data extract we are using allows longitudinal linkage because some of the people who took part in the 2015 focus groups later participated in a 1-2-1 telephone interview.
The data citations:

Carvalho, E., Winters, K., Oliver, T. (2023). The Qualitative Election Study of Britain: The EU Referendum Interviews Dataset, 2016. [data collection]. UK Data Service. SN: 856170, DOI
Some more information:

title: Qualitative Election Study of Britain
text:
Open research
This dataset is a brilliant example of Open Science: the data are open access but also organised to promote reusability. This is good practice, and there a lot of resources to help guide you on the use and reuse of secondary data, and how you can play your part.
For more information on open research and data:

The FAIR principles to improve the findability, accessibility, interoperability, and reuse of digital assets.
UK Data Service hub for archiving qualitative data and secondary analysis.
Take one of these free data skills modules from the UK Data Service which covers topics like research data management, finding secondary data, data resuse and many more topics.



Open Qualitative Research






ğŸ¤¢ Itâ€™s not you, itâ€™s NVivo



Important to making data and analysis open is storing it in an â€˜interoperableâ€™ and â€˜openâ€™ format. Interoperable means that the files are not restricted to being opened by a specific single application, such as NVivo. An open standard is one that is available for anyone to use, share, or access - where it could be opened on NVivo, Atlas.ti, and so on.
Fully â€˜open researchâ€™ remains limited within qualitative research for various reasons. One important limitation is whilst there is an interoperable open QDPX format for sharing qualitative data analysis projects, it is a â€˜lossyâ€™ format â€“ where folder structures and more are lost when exporting to the open format.
So, although it is possible to export to QDPX and import it to a different application - such as exporting from NVivo and importing in Atlas.ti - any folder structure and other aspects would be lost in the process.

title: What is coding?
text:
Section Overview



Within this section we will cover the conceptual grounding for qualitative coding and set through the basic processes for creating codes and coding within NVivo.



What are codes?

Codes are tags or containers for complex qualitative data; they are a way to index, sort, link and interrogate data.
The process of coding involves finding ways of summarizing key meanings within your data.
The same piece of text can have multiple meanings or codes.




Deductive vs inductive coding
In deductive coding, you approach your dataset with a pre-established list of codes, often based off existing theoretical frameworks or even the research tools themselves (e.g.Â the questions that were asked). This is a more top-down, etic approach that is most useful for confirming or testing existing theories, or imposing organizational and structure into your file (e.g.Â coding by interview guide or research questions).
Conversely, inductive coding occurs when you allow codes to emerge from your engagement with the dataset itself, with no preconceived categories. This is a bottom up, emic approach to coding.
Your own approach may be heavily influenced by your discipline, research aims, and research questions.
However, most work will be situated in a hybrid space between the two.


Coding as iterative
Sorry folks, qualitative coding is far from one-and-done. Coding is a cyclical, ongoing process. Interviews cannot be read and coded just once. As we re-read our datasets, we continue to develop new codes and subcodes, and refine our understanding of the data. Each time we read our material, we gain a deeper level of understanding each time we read our transcripts. With each pass, we will notice new things, which may prompt us to read new academic articles or ask different questions. This work will in turn shape what we see and understand in our next reading of the dataset. Nvivo can help us organise and interrogate codes but coding is led by the researcher.


The practice of coding
Remember, when coding in Nvivo:

Codes can overlap
Codes will sort themselves to be alphabetical list â€“ so clear, direct, short codes are helpful.
Consider your future self (and any collaborators), and try to annotate your coding by always including a code description: what you think this code means and what should be included here
Codes should change as your project changes. They can be combined and rearranged.
Donâ€™t be afraid to make a code because youâ€™re uncertain if it will be relevant or important enough. Theyâ€™re a tool to think with and can always be adjusted later.

Be careful: try not to code when tired, bored, or distracted â€“ you must always be actively thinking (the â€˜organic computerâ€™ [your brain] is the primary tool of analysis).



Autocoding?
You might have heard about autocoding in Nvivo. Donâ€™t worry- it is not advanced enough to replace the essential work of a researcher.
This is currently a basic - but often useful- functionality in Nvivo. It can help you organise the text into cases or themes based on pre-defined criteria (weâ€™ll show you these below!)
However it is the researcherâ€™s job to interpret and make meaning from data.


Different approaches to coding - learn more
See resources tab for more information about various approaches to coding.
